loans.name: Sofia

texts.es:
I need to build an additional room in my patio because my husband and I need more space. Our home is very small since it is public housing, so we would like to expand our house. However, we will have to expand it little by little due to our difficult financial situation. I am requesting $500.00 USD in order to construct an extra room in my house.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

“Tengo la necesidad de hacer un cuarto en el patio de mi vivienda ya que mi esposo y yo necesitamos más espacio porque la casa es de interés social y son muy reducidas, tenemos la intención de ir haciendo nuestra casa más grande pero tendrá que ser poco a poco debido a que la situación económica esta muy difícil” Solicito $ 500.00 dlls para construir un cuarto en mi vivienda.

loans.use: Construction of a room

loans.name: Thi Hao

texts.vi:
Mrs Thuyên is 54. She works as a farmer and raises pigs. She lives with her son and his wife, they are both skilled woodworkers. Her family income is 200000-300000 VND a day (~12.50 - 18.85 usd a day). She would like to borrow 2006000 VND to buy pig mash. She likes to borrow from SEDA because it does not require collateral, the loan officers are nice and helpful. They even go to her house to distribute the loan.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Thuyên, 59 tuổi, làm ruộng và chăn nuôi lợn. Chị sống cùng con trai và con dâu đều là những thợ mộc lành nghề của thôn. Thu nhập gia đình chị từ 200000-300000đồng/ ngày. Chị muốn vay 2006000 đồng để mua cám cho lợn ăn. Chị rất thích vay vốn của chương trình tài chính vi mô binhminh cdc vì không phải thế chấp, cán bộ tín dụng lại rất thân thiện, hướng dẫn tận tình, lại xuống tận nơi để thu phát vốn, chị không phải đi xa vất vả nữa.

loans.use: buy pig mash

loans.name: Pech

texts.en:
Mrs. Pech T. is 45 years old and sells bags, earning about $4.83 per day. Her business depends on mobility around the markets. Mrs. T. buys bags from Oreusey Market in Phnom Penh and spends the rest of the day transporting them. T. has three children, all young students. Her husband, Mr. Bo Ben, also sells bags with her, earning around $4.83 per day. They live in Baray District, Kampong Thom Province.

Mrs.T. requests a loan of $400 to buy more bags to sell. In the future, she hopes to buy a plot of land near the main road and open a small shop to sell her bags. She hopes to achieve her goal by using this loan. T., Ben, and their child appear in the photo.

loans.use: To buy more bags to sell

loans.name: Rosas Rojas Group

texts.es:
Behind the look of a group of timid women one never knows what experiences can be found and in this case business initiatives also.

The Red Roses group explained to me something that I would never have been able to contemplate and that is that, without an infusion of capital, they would not be able to create their own separate business. Without the loan they would continue being employees of someone else, earning a minimum wage which would not give them enough to either begin a career or leave poverty.

Nevertheless, the adult women told me that at the moment of receiving a loan they are touched, but at the same time they feel a little fear because they do not know if they are going to be able repay the debt. It is a very understandable feeling since is a new experience through which they and all the women of their generation are passing. In spite of that, they have already completed five loans with Friendship Bridge.

A detail that leaps to light was that the majority of members of this group worked selling second-hand items. Four clients commented that they went to the city of Guatemala, a trip of approximately four hours, to buy second-hand items in order to sell them in Suchitepequez which is a regional capital that is located to another four hours from the town of Nahuala. The interesting thing about these trips is that the women travel to completely different destinations and therefore compete with people from other cultures that are not theirs. This is something really impressive since traditionally the women are confined inside a native community and do not tend to travel a lot. Another detail that reflects a modernist cut of this group is that ten women among the youths and adults have just bought cell phones.

Two clients will invest their credit in wood to work in carpentry. Two others have a bakery. Others sell and weave clothes. As can be seen in this group one can find a variety of important businesses.

The Red Roses is a group of women that is exploring different roads, so that in some way they can avoid being faced with the saturation of the market by opting for businesses that have not been explored by the remainder of women in their communities. Supporting a group of creative and innovative women is important to promote the development of micro-business and of Guatemala. Thanks for your consideration.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Detrás la mirada de un grupo de mujeres tímidas uno nunca sabe que experiencias puede extraer de ellas y en este caso iniciativas empresariales también.

Las Rosas Rojas me explicaron algo que nunca hubiera podido contemplar y eso es que sin infusión de capital, su negocio no podría despegar. Sin el crédito ellas seguirían siendo empleadas de alguien más ganando una cantidad mínima la cual no las dejaría ni empezar la carrera de salir de la pobreza.

Sin embargo, las mujeres adultas me comentaron que a la hora de sacar un crédito ellas se emocionan, pero a la vez sienten un poco de temor porque no van a saber si van a poder repagar la deuda. Es un sentimiento muy entendible ya que es una experiencia nueva por las cuales ellas y todas las mujeres de su generación están pasando. A pesar de eso, ya llevaban con Friendship Bridge cinco créditos.

Un detalle que salto a luz fue que la mayoría de integrantes de este grupo trabajaban vendiendo trastes. Cuatro clientas comentaron que se iban a la ciudad de Guatemala un viaje de aproximadamente cuatro horas a comprar trastes para luego irlos a vender hasta Suchitepequez la cual es una cabecera departamental que está ubicada a otras cuatro horas del pueblo de Nahuala. Lo interesante de estos viajes es que las mujeres viajan a destinos completamente distintos y por ende lidiando con gente de otras culturas que no son las suyas. Algo realmente impresionante ya que tradicionalmente las mujeres dentro de una comunidad indígena están confinadas y no tienden a viajar mucho. Otro detalle que refleja un corte vanguardista de este grupo es que diez mujeres entre jóvenes y adultas acaban de comprar celulares.

Dos clientas invierten su crédito en madera para trabajar en carpintería. Otras dos tienen un panadería, otras venden y tejen ropa. Como se puede ver en este grupo uno puede encontrar una variedad de negocios importante.

Las Rojas Rosas es un grupo de mujeres que está explorando distintos caminos, que de alguna manera están evitando enfrentarse a la saturación de mercado al optar por negocios no muy explorado por el resto de mujeres en sus comunidades. Apoyar a un grupo de mujeres innovadoras y creativas es importante para promover el desarrollo de la microempresa y de Guatemala. Gracias por tomarlas en cuenta.

loans.use: To buy seond-hand items and clothes for resale, thread for weaving, supplies for a bakery, products for a convenience store, and wood for carpentry.

loans.name: Saron Pho Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Saron P. is the leader of a five-person business group in Samrith Chey Village in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. She is a mat maker in the local village. She is 30 and the mother of four children, three of whom attend school while the youngest is too young to work or study. Her husband, Mr. Sokhom Phann, is a subsistence farmer.

Mrs. Saron P.’s business has improved, but she has a small problem because, she does not have enough money to buy more raw materials to make the mats that she needs to expand her business. Mrs. Saron P. has decided to ask for a loan for this purpose.

loans.use: To buy raw materials to make more mats to sell

loans.name: Hoa Thi Nguyen's Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. Hoa Thi N. (SEDA ID: 050037), is 44 year old. She borrows 2,242,000 Vietnamese Dong to buy inventory wood for her plan of producing tables. She, along with the group, has participated in 1loan term and repaid on time. After the first time borrowing money to raise small farming animals, she could save some money. Therefore, she wants to keep on participating in the program. Her family incomes are 120,000 Vietnamese Dong, approximately $7.56, per day. She has 3 children, who are also contributing to the family budget.

In the group, there are the following individuals:

Mrs. Chuyen Thi N. (SEDA ID: 050036) borrows 2,714,000 Vietnamese Dong to participate in beef retailing in the local market.

Mrs. Sau Thi N. (SEDA ID: 050038) borrows 2,006,000 Vietnamese Dong to raise pigs and buy and sell metal waste.

Mrs. Nguyet Thi N. (SEDA ID: 050040) borrows 2,242,000 Vietnamese Dong to raise chickens and pigs.

Mrs. Ngu Thi L. (SEDA ID: 050041) borrows 2,242,000 Vietnamese Dong to raise chickens.

Mrs. Tha Thi N. (SEDA ID: 050037) borrows 2,242,000 Vietnamese Dong to buy and sell firewood.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer.

Cô Nguyễn Thị Hoa (MS: 050037), năm nay 44 tuổi. Cô vay 2.242.000 VND bổ sung vốn mua gỗ để đóng bàn. Cô cùng cả nhóm đã tham gia được một chu kỳ vay và đã hoàn trả rất tốt. Lần một cô vay để chăn nuôi và thấy mình tiết kiệm được. Vì vậy cô tiếp tục tham gia chương trình. Mức thu nhập của gia đình cô là 120.000 VND/ngày. Cô có 3 con đã đi làm giúp đỡ được cô rất nhiều trong việc chi tiêu cho gia đình.

  • Trong nhóm cô còn có:
  • Chị Nguyễn Thị Chuyền (MS: 050036), vay 2.714.000 VND để mua thịt bò bán ở chợ.
  • Chị Nguyễn Thị Sáu (MS: 050038), vay 2.006.000 VND để chăn nuôi lợn và bổ sung vốn đi buôn phế liệu.
  • Chị Nguyễn Thị Nguyệt (MS: 050040), vay 2.242.000 VND để chăn nuôi gà, lợn.
  • Chị Lê Thị Ngữ (MS: 050041), vay 2.242.000 VND để chăn nuôi gà.
  • Chị Nguyễn Thị Thả (MS: 050039), vay 2.242.000 VND để mua củi bán.

loans.use: Agricultural product sales; table production, and raising

loans.name: Aissatou Ibra

texts.fr:
58-year-old Aissatou Ibra D. is married and cares for one child. She has been a member of the Tenghory Transgambian village bank for two and a half years. Aissatou Ibra trades in a dyed fabric called thioub, other fabrics and cloth. She wishes to improve their standard of living and health. The loan which she is requesting would be repaid in a lump sum in six months’ time.

Translated from French by Joyce, Kiva Volunteer.

Aissatou Ibra D. 58 ans, mariée avec 01 enfant en charge est membre du banc villageois de Tenghory Transgambienne depuis 2 ans et demi. Son activité consiste à acheter et revendre des thioubs(tissus teintés), tissus et draps. Elle souhaite améliorer les conditions de vie et de santé. Le prêt qu'elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use: Fabric sales, including thioub dyed fabrics

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.vi: Trước khi tham gia Qũy tình thương, cửa hàng của chị H. chỉ là một cửa hàng nhỏ chủ yếu phục vụ khách quen và những người xung quanh. Năm 2003 chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương vay mức 2.000.000đ để mua thêm một số mỹ phẩm và trang thiết bị cho cửa hàng nhờ vậy khách hàng đến cửa hàng của chị ngày một đông, thu nhập của chị được nâng lên từ 70.000đ - 100.000đ /ngày. Trải qua 5năm vay vốn chị luôn sử dụng vốn  tập trung cho mua sắm, nâng cấp trang thiết bị cho cửa hàng. Đặc biệt, chị đã tham gia lớp đào tạo về trang điểm để tư vấn thêm cho khách hàng khi mua mỹ phẩm. Hiện tại,cửa hàng của chị khang trang và tấp nập nhất nhì khu phố Để đáp ứng tốt nhu cầu của khách hàng chị phải thuê thêm 1 người làm thường xuyên với mức lương 1.000.000đ/tháng, trong dịp cuối năm chị phải thuê thêm 2 người để bán hàng. Thu nhập bình quân của cửa hàng  là 5.000.000/tháng. Chị mong muốn được  vay 17.000.000đ để mua thêm các loại mỹ phẩm cao cấp và trang thiết bị hiện đại để  có thể phục vụ khách hàng một cách tốt nhất.
texts.en:
Mrs. H. joined TYM Fund in 2003. In the first round of loan, she borrowed 2.000.000 VND to purchase cosmetic products and equipment for her salon. Before joining TYM, her shop was small; customers were often acquaintances. But since she invested more in her salon with the help of TYM, it has become increasingly popular, helping her earn about 70.000 to 100.000 per day. For the past 5 years, Mrs. H. has been using loans from TYM Fund to purchase new equipment, enhancing the quality of her salon. She also attended a make-up course, so she can give advice to her customers. As a result, her salon is now one of the best in her area. Now, Mrs. H. has to hire one employee to help her with all the work, with a salary of 1.000.000 VND per month. At the end of the year in particular, she has to hire 2 persons to assist her. Mrs. H.’s monthly income is 5.000.000 VND. In the next round of loan, she would like to borrow 17.000.000 VND ($1025) to purchase more high-quality cosmetic products and modern equipment for her salon to attract more customers.

Translated from Vietnamese by KH. Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: business

loans.name: Dora

texts.en:
Dora A. lives in Afromedia in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 42 years old and married with eight children. She sells provisions and drinks.

Dora is a LAPO client. She needs a loan for $700 to buy more drinks and provisions to sell. Dora desires to pull her family out of poverty. She thanks everyone that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more drinks and provisions to sell.

loans.name: Hélène

texts.fr: Dame A. Hélène est née le 18/08/1972 à Cotonou. Elle est mariée à SOSSOUHOUNTO Franck , couturier brodeur. Après son échec au Certificat d'Etude Primaire(C.E.P) elle a été apprentie coiffeuse pendant un an. Ensuite elle s'est lancée dans la vente de divers produits vivriers à savoir haricot, riz et divers autres articles qu'elle a héritée de sa défunte grande sœur. Elle sollicite ce second prêt en vue d'accroître son capital et renforcer son activité. Elle compte surtout s'approvisionner en riz.
texts.en:
Mrs. Hélène A. was born on 08/18/1972 in Cotonou. She is married to Franck SOSSOUHOUNTO, a dressmaker-embroiderer. After she failed her primary school exit certificate, she became an apprentice hairdresser for one year. Then she launched herself in the sale of various food products such as beans, rice and various other articles that she inherited from her late older sister. She is requesting this second loan in order to increase her capital and to strengthen her activity. She wishes to buy mostly rice.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of 50 bags of rice

loans.name: Fatou's Group

texts.fr: L'écovillage de MbouM. est situé dans la région de Saint Louis à 300 km de Dakar. La  Population de gandiol s'estime à 13968 habitants. Les principales activités économiques dans la zone sont : le commerce, la pêche, le maraichage, l'élevage et l'extraction du sel. Cependant du fait de la péjoration climatique et des phénomènes anthropiques, le niveau de dégradation et de désorganisation est ressenti par sa communauté entière. Les femmes du groupement Mouit ayant bénéficié d'un premier prêt qui leur avait permis de réaliser leurs rêves reviennent auprès de Kiva pour solliciter un renouvellement. Avec le prêt, elles vont acheter des semences, de l'engrais, du fumier, des pulvérisateurs pour faire du maraichage. Les produits récoltés, elles espèrent développer le marché local par la création d'un système d'approvisionnement et de commercialisation de fruits et légumes
texts.en:
The ecovillage of MbouM. is located in the Saint Louis region 300 km from Dakar. The population of Gandiol is about 13,968 inhabitants. The principal economic activities in the area are: commerce, fishing, truck farming, farming and extracting salt. However, due to the climatic decline and anthropogenic phenomena, the level of decline and disruption is felt by the entire community. The women of the Mouit group, having benefited from a first loan which allowed them to realize their dreams, are coming back to Kiva to seek a renewal. With this loan, they are going to buy seed, fertilizer, manure, and sprays in order to do truck farming. With the crops, they hope to grow the local market by creating a system of supply and commercialization of fruits and vegetables.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: truck farming

loans.name: Rashid's Group

texts.en:
Rashid Mizungi, age 30, is married with one child of four. He has a welding business which he started 18 years ago and he works daily from 7am until 6pm. He is able to earn a monthly profit of about US$ 285.

This will be Rashid’s second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loan to buy materials for making gates, doors, and windows and he repaid the loan successfully. He now hopes for a second loan to open a shop to start selling things like saucepans, stove, and frying pans.

Rashid will share this loan with subgroup A of the Tunaweza group. The subgroup has 2 members; the other one sells clothes. These members hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Rashid is the man.

loans.use: To open a shop for selling thing like saucepans, frying pans, and stoves

loans.name: Le Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Lê Thị Hoàn, 28 tuổi,chị đang sống cùng chồng và 1 con nhỏ tại Quảng Xương Thanh Hoá. Hiện tại chị đang kinh doanh săm lốp ô tô còn chồng chị làm nghề lái xe. Với thu nhập 4.000.000 đ/ tháng việc hàon trả vốn của gia đình chị Hoàn cũng rất thuận lợi. 
Chị Hoàn đang mong muốn được vay 5.000.000đ để đầu tư thêm vốn vào công việc kinh doanh của gia đình.
texts.en:
Lê Thị Hoàn is 28 years old. She lives in Quảng Xương Thanh Hoá with her husband and their young child. She sells car tires & tube and her husband is a truck driver. Thei combined income is 4.000.000 VND a month. She has no problem repaying the loan money. She is requesting 5.000.000 VND to invest in her business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to invest in her tire & tube business

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en: Blessing O. is 45 years old and married with 2 children who are in school, Blessing sells fairly used clothes. She travels to Cotonou, a seaport town in a neighboring country, every 2 weeks to purchase fairly used clothes to sell. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She is requesting the loan amount of N 50,000 to purchase more fairly used clothes to sell. She says thanks to Kiva and all lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more fairly used clothes to sell

loans.name: Daniel Pascual

texts.es:
El Sr. Daniel M., se encuentra en su primera secuencia de créditos, es un cliente recomendado por la Sra. Remedios M. quien es cliente antigua y muy responsable en Emprender.
Daniel trabaja como transportista desde sus 18 años a la fecha tiene 26 años, vive con su mamá, una Sra. de edad, muy sociable, además de sus hermanas y sobrinos, con quienes comparte las horas de descanso y a veces el almuerzo, son una familia muy unida.
El joven adquirió su movilidad con un crédito de otra Institución bancaria y está pagando esa deuda a largo plazo, puntualmente. Dicha movilidad se encuentra trabajando en la Empresa Eurosur como Radio taxi.
Por el buen historial que a la fecha presenta, se aprobó el crédito que solicitó con la garantía personal de su hermana.
texts.en:
Mr. Daniel M., who is in his first sequence of loans, is a client recommended by Mrs. Remedios M., who is an old, very responsible client of Emprender. Daniel has worked as a transportation carrier for 18 years and is 26 years old. He lives with his elderly, friendly mother. They, along with his sisters and nieces and nephews, with whom he spends his leisure time and sometimes lunchtime, are a close-knit family. The youth acquired his vehicle with a loan from another banking institution, and he is paying this debt punctually in long installments. This vehicle is operating in Empresa Eurosur as a Radio taxi. For the good record that he has to date, he was approved for this loan, which he requested with the guarantee of his sister.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To change the shock absorbers in his vehicle

loans.name: Masuda

texts.en:
Masuda T. applied first to MicroInvest in 2009 and she liked the loan procedure, so she is taking a business support loan. Masuda lives in B.Gafurov region of Tajikistan. She is married and has two children. 

Masuda sells food products at a mini-market that she opened in her own home. She has an assortment of vegetable oil, sugar, macaroni, tea, etc. 

Masuda is asking for a loan of 1600 STJ for 4 months to expand her assortment of goods.

loans.use: To expand her assortment of goods

loans.name: Houssein

texts.en:
Houssein is a 47 year old man who lives with his wife and their two children in Tyre, southern Lebanon. Houssein works in agriculture. Houssein requested a loan of 700 U.S. dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools and merchandise for his work. This is the first time that Houssein has requested a loan.

Houssein is special because he has experience. When he first started his business, he had financial issues. Houssein chose his business because he wanted to improve his family’s income. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase tools and merchandise for his work

loans.name: Tasi

texts.en:
Tasi S., 50, is married with four children. She has many years of experience in her taro (a root vegetable) and banana plantation business. She sells three days per week to the village community and to the general public. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (approximately $100).

Tasi has two previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are her only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To buy fence wire, containers for water storage, bushknives and an electric chainsaw

loans.name: Martha

texts.es:
Martha es socia del Banco Comunal Paraíso.
Martha es viuda, tiene 57 años y 7 hijos, Martha vende cebiches en su casa, actividad que realiza todos los días por la mañana. Martha tiene proyectado implementar una tienda de abarrotes.
Martha necesita un préstamo de 900 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de gaseosas, pescado.
Los sueños de Martha son que sus últimos 3 hijos sean profesionales, construir su casa de material noble y ampliar sus negocios.
texts.en:
Martha is a member of the Paradise Communal Bank. Martha is a widow, is 57 years old and has 7 children. Martha sells ceviche in her home, an activity that she carries out every morning. Martha plans to start a grocery store. Martha needs a loan of 900 soles, money which will be invested in the purchase of soft drinks and fish. Martha's dreams are for her last 3 children to become professionals, to build a house made of noble material and to grow her businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Aimee Sostowski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of soft drinks and fish.

loans.name: Juan

texts.en:
Juan R. sells plates and cups in a shop and is requesting a loan to purchase more goods to sell. Juan is 29 years old and married. Her husband is a driver. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more goods to sell in her shop.

loans.name: 6 De Julio Group

texts.en:
This group, from the San Pedro Cucupayty neighborhood, emerged through advertising meetings in the area. All of the women have their own respective businesses. Each woman uses the credit given to her to invest in her current activities. 

1.	Jiner A. B.  -  tailor shop 
2.	Nilda O. D. G.  -  food sales 
3.	Eliodora P. D. G.  -  small grocery store 
4.	Mariela Esther P. D. G.  -  cell phone sales 
5.	Olga Isabel R. D.  -  cosmetics sales 
6.	Hilda Aidee F. A.  -  raising & sale of chickens 
7.	Ramona Isabel L. B.  -  general store 
8.	Carmen Elizabeth A. D.  -  food sales 
9.	Marcela Leopoldina P. A.  -  dressmaker 
10.	Carmen Griselda G. F. 
11.	Angelina S.  -  food sales 
12.	Ofelia M.  -  chicken sales 
13.	Virginia T. Díaz  -  food sales 
14.	Johana O. Y.  -  handicraft sales 
15.	Gerónima O. G.  -  handicraft sales 
16.	Verónica Vanesa G. O.  -  cosmetics sales

loans.use: To purchase raw materials or merchandise for sale.

loans.name: Mabondeli Plus Group

texts.fr: David K. est président d’un groupe qui évolue avec Hope RDC dénommé « Mabondeli Plus ». Il gère sa propre cabine téléphonique qui se situe dans le quartier populaire à l’est de Kinshasa. David est entré dans le monde des micro-entreprises en 1993. Il allait dans des villages faire le troc en échangeant des poissons salés et des savons aux sacs de manioc et maїs qu’il revendait à Kinshasa. Cette activité l’a soutenu pour terminer ses études secondaires en 1998. Après la fermeture de la société où il travaillait en 2002, David s’est de nouveau lancé dans le troc dans des villages jusqu’en 2002 lorsqu’il a ouvert sa cabine téléphonique à Kinshasa grâce aux bénéfices accumulés. Il compte avec le prochain prêt de Hope acheter des cartes prépayées à revendre pour accroitre le revenu de son affaire qui lui génère un bénéfice de $35 par semaine. Son ambition est d’ouvrir une pharmacie à cause du besoin croissant en médicaments. David est âgé de 36 ans, marié et père de 4 enfants dont leurs âges varient entre 2 et 8 ans. Deux d’entre eux vont à l’école primaire.
texts.en:
David K. is president of a group that started with Hope RDC and is called “Mabondeli Plus.” He runs his own telephone booth in a busy neighborhood east of Kinshasa. David entered the world of micro-business in 1993. He would go from village to village bartering salted fish and soap for bags of cassava and corn, which he then sold in Kinshasa. This business supported him while he finished his high school studies in 1998. After the company where he was working closed in 2002, David once again took up bartering in different villages until he opened his own telephone booth in Kinshasa in 2002 using the profits he had accumulated. He plans to use the next loan from Hope to buy prepaid phone cards and sell them in order to increase the income from his business, which provides him with a weekly profit of $35. His ambition is to open a pharmacy, given the increasing need for medicines. David is 36 years old, married and the father of four children aged between two and eight. Two of the children are at primary school.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy prepaid phone cards to sell in order to increase the income generated by the business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more material and a new sewing machine

loans.name: Jean Carla

texts.en:
Jean CarL. is 28 years old and has two children. She is a single parent. Jean CarL. and her sister have a decoration service. They use cloth and balloons to decorate rooms for parties and other events. They also rent out chairs.

Jean CarL. has been working with Kiva partner ManueL. Ramos for two years and is a member of the communal bank “Las Triunfadoras” (The Winners). She used her very first loan of 300 soles to purchase fabrics for her business. She plans to use this loan of 1500 soles to buy a motorcycle taxi. This vehicle will enable her to more easily transport the chairs and decorating materials that she uses in her business.

Jean CarL. has been using her loans from ManueL. Ramos to purchase more supplies for her business, which has been doing well. Jean CarL. is working hard in order to be able to purchase her own house.

loans.use: A motorcycle taxi to transport materials for a decoration service.

loans.name: Ganna

texts.en:
Ganna is married and has two adult sons. She sells fruits and vegetables at the central market in Ivano-Frankovsk. Ganna started this business when she lost her job as result of downsizement at the meat factory where she worked. For the past 12 years this business has been the main source of her family income. 
Ganna would like to borrow 6,500 UAH to purchase more of seasonal inventories. She hopes to make some additional income and use it for coming wedding of her son.

loans.use: to purchase more inventories

loans.name: Amistad Rsr. Group

texts.es: El Banco Comunal denominado  AMISTAD RSR  Esta representado por la señora Ángela Elvira y por doce socias que en su mayoría radican en la zona D. Villa victoria y van cursando juntas ya su 5to ciclo demostrando responsabilidad, honestidad y ganas D. trabajar. La mayoría D. las socias se dedican a la administración D. sus vehículos y/o al manejo D. los mismos, pertenecen a la línea D. radio taxi "Punto Car", que esta en funcionamiento alrededor D. 10 años con el servicio,  otras socias se dedican al tejidos D. redes D. arco D. fútbol, una D. las socias se dedica a la venta D. víveres y otra a la venta D. ropa en la feria. El mercado que atacan es muy competitivo, pero según al producto y la oferta que se tenga obtienen ventas favorables para poder cancelar sus obligaciones y mantener a sus familias. El destino del crédito es para compra D. repuestos y mantenimiento D. sus movilidades, compra D. víveres, y materia prima para el tejido y mercadería en general D. ropa. Los antecedentes D. las socias con otras instituciones son positivos por lo cual se vio por conveniente darle un nuevo apoyo económico para que sigan creciendo juntas.
texts.en:
The AMISTAD RSR Community Bank is represented by Ángela Elvira and has twelve members, most based in the Villa Victoria area. They are now on their fifth loan cycle together, having demonstrated their responsibility, honesty and desire to work. The members are in the main engaged in managing and/or driving their vehicles, as members of the "Punto Car" radio taxi service, which has been in operation for some 10 years now. Other members make football goal netting, one sells groceries while another sells clothing at market. Although they operate within a highly competitive sector, they achieve good levels of sales depending on the product and offer, allowing them to meet their payments and maintain their families. The loan will be used for spare parts and maintenance for their vehicles, the purchase of foodstuffs and raw materials for weaving, and general items of clothing. The members have positive experiences of other institutions, serving as the basis for this renewed economic support allowing them to continue growing in partnership.

Translated from Spanish by Matthew Clapham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating Capital

loans.name: Silvia Elizabeth

texts.es: La señora Silvia Elizabeth  y su esposo  Samuel son padres de un pequeñito, ella trabaja para un medico como asistente en una clínica, y su esposo labora para una empresa en el área de operador desde hace 9 años. Ellos son una familia muy trabajadora y unida la cual está solicitando esta crédito para la instalación del techo de lamina de dos cuartos en su vivienda para así tener una mayor comodidad en su hogar.
texts.en:
Silvia Elizabeth and her husband, Samuel, have a small child. She works as an assistant for a doctor in a clinic. Her husband has worked as an operator for a business for nine years. They are a hard-working and united family. They are asking for this loan to install a laminate roof on two rooms in their house. This way they will be more comfortable in their home.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Place a laminate roof on two rooms

loans.name: Johnbull

texts.en: Johnbull is 40 years old, married and has six children. For the last seven years, he has made a living as a farmer. He is applying for this loan to buy more seedlings to plant and raise on his farm. He extends his thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To buy more seedlings to plant and raise on his farm

loans.name: Ifeoma

texts.en: Ifeoma is a focused, hard worker. She puts in long hours trying to keep her business sustainable. One of her greatest joys is the one-on-one interaction she is able to have with her customers.  She sells sarongs, children clothes and bathing soap at retail prices in Asaba, Delta state, Nigeria.  She is 32 years old and married with three children. She hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en: Myrna E. is from the village of Misom, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 34 years old, married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Myrna owns & operates a business venture in the arts sector rating a beautician.While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing manicures and pedicures in the local community. Myrna has been engaged in her business for over 2 years. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase additional materials for manicure and pedicure

loans.name: Abilio

texts.pt:
Abílio T. nasceu na cidade da Matola, Província de Maputo, tem 53 anos de idade, casado e pai de 1 filho de 28 anos de idade que frequenta a escola. Abílio fez 9ª classe e não continuou por falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa própria com sua família, sustenta a mãe que vive com ela e ainda sua filha em despesas escolares e alimentares.

Nunca mudou do sítio onde vive, construiu uma nova residência ao lado da casa dos pais e vive com a sua família ate hoje. É negociante a tempo inteiro e dono do seu próprio negocio há mais de 25 anos, faz em media cerca de 10 horas por dia e tem um rendimento de cerca de 12.000.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum no banco comercial BIM.

Já teve empréstimos com a cooperativa de crédito TCHUMA, mais tarde conheceu a Hluvuku através de vizinhos que também são clientes desta instituição e decidiu solicitar o seu 1º empréstimo. Este é o seu 3º empréstimo no valor de 15.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos (Cervejas, sumos, bebidas secas e refrescos) para aumentar a mercadoria do seu estabelecimento. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 9.000.00mt e 15.500.00mt todos para a mesma actividade.
 
No futuro gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para ampliar o seu estaleiro e comprar uma viatura como meio de ajudar no transporte da sua mercadoria.
texts.en:
Abílio T. was born in the city of Matola, in the Maputo province. He is 53 years old, married and father of a 28 years old son who attends school. Abílio studied up to the 9th grade e did not continue due to lack of financial conditions. He lives in his own house with his family and supports his mother, who lives with him. He also pays his daughter's school and food expenses.

He has never moved from the place where he lives. He has built a new house beside his parents' house, and there is where he lives with his family today. He is a full-time trader, and the owner of his business for more than 25 years. He works in average 10 hours a day, and earns approximately MZN 12,000 a month. He uses his earning to pay for the house expenses and he also saves some money at the commercial bank BIM.

He has had loans from the credit union TCHUMA. Later on, he learned about Hluvuku through neighbors who are also clients of this institution and decided to request his first loan. This is his third loan, of MZN 15,000, with which he intends to buy products (beer, juice, dry beverages and soft drinks) in order to increase his merchandise. The former loans were of MZN 9,000 and MZN 15,500, all destined to the same activity.

In the future, he wishes to request more loans in order to expand his yard and to buy a vehicle as means to transport merchandise.


Translated from Portuguese by Giovanna Fernandes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy and selling of merchandise (beer, soft drinks, juice and others)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Fixing up a village pharmacy

loans.name: Erdenetogtoh

texts.en: Erdenetogtoh C. is 36 years old and lives with her husband and four children in Uvs, one of the western provinces of Mongolia. Her family lives in a "ger", a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. All of her four children attend a local secondary school. Together with her husband, Erdenetogtoh operates grocery a trading business and a meat and livestock retail business in their town. She runs the family grocery store while her husband purchases meat and livestock from the countryside and then transports and sells them through their store and in the center of the province where the meat fetches higher prices. She started her business in 2006. Erdenetogtoh is requesting a 2,500,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase a large number of livestock for the upcoming winter months which her husband can sell at a high profit margin in the center of the province.

loans.use: To purchase a large number of livestock

loans.name: Jose Irnel

texts.en:
Mr. Jose Irnel G. comes from Molave, Zamboanga del Sur. He is forty years old and married with three children. Jose Irnel operates a sari-sari (variety) store, though his main source of income comes from his boarding house. He has managed his store for almost two years and earns approximately $135 a month.

In 2009, he joined PMPC to gain access to financial support and to improve his living situation and his ability to be engaged in business activities. He successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP. This will be his 3rd loan from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue to expand his business and also to improve the general living conditions of his family.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: additional capital for his sari-sari  store

loans.name: Maria Eloisa

texts.es:
La Sra. María Eloisa, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Honestidad y Trabajo”, Distrito de Juanjui, Provincia de Mariscal Cáceres, Departamento de San Martín. Es Soltera, tiene 41 años y es madre de 02 hijos, que aun dependen de ella, presenta Estudios Superiores Incompletos de Educación Inicial.

María Eloisa, lleva 15 años dedicándose a la confección de vestidos, ya que teniendo conocimiento en este tipo de actividad, no dudo en implementar su propio taller de costura, ubicada en su misma casa, en un ambiente muy bien acondicionado, donde diariamente atiende a sus clientes fijos, que ya la conocen y necesitan el servicio. Trabaja con pedidos anticipados que sus clientes le solicitan y siempre regalando una sonrisa ellos se sienten muy contentos y satisfechos. En la actualidad, se siente una mujer realizada, con ganas de siempre salir adelante .que a podido sobresalir gracias esta muy contenta y orgullosa por lo logrado. 

Con el préstamo de S/. 3,000.00 Nuevos Soles, comprará telas en metros, de diferentes especies y colores, instrumentos que utiliza como tijeras, hilos en carretes grande y de variados colores, agujas de coser y de maquina, alfileres, botones, blondas, etc.

Hoy en día se siente una mujer muy feliz y esta muy orgullosa por lo logrado, su sueño es tener un local más amplio. Agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudarla a iniciar su negocio y también a muchas mujeres que  quieren crecer y salir adelante.
texts.en:
María Eloisa, 41, is a member of the "Honestidad y Trabajo" (Honesty & Work) communal bank, which is in Juanjui district, Mariscal Cáceres province, San Martín department. She is single and has two children, who are dependent on her. She did not finish secondary school. María Eloisa has been a seamstress for 15 years. Having knowledge and skills in this activity, she did not hesistate to set up her own workshop, in her home, in a well-equipped area to receive her regular customers daily. They know her and require her services. She works based on prior orders from her customer and she always has a ready smile for them; they are happy and satisfied. Currently, she feels that she is a fulfilled woman, who has the desire to succeed and who has already succeeded; she is happy and proud of her accomplishments. She will use the 3000 new sol loan to buy fabric of various colors and types, tools like scissors, large-spool thread of various colors, sewing and sewing machine needles, pins, buttons, blondas (lace-like material used in cuffs and collars), etc. Today she is happy and proud of what she has accomplished. Her dream is to have a larger shop. She is grateful to the Manuela Ramos Movement for helping her start her business and other women who want to grow and succeed.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabric.

loans.name: Pélagie

texts.fr: V. Pélagie est née le 31 août 1963 à Cotonou. Pélagie est veuve et mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés et tous à sa charge.  Pélagie vit seule avec les enfants à Djeffa, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, depuis 20 ans.  Pélagie a fréquenté l’école jusqu’au cours secondaire. Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Pélagie mène comme activité, la vente des objets de piété (livrets de prière, chapelet, images, etc.) ainsi que des pots de fleurs devant l’Eglise catholique de Djeffa. Pélagie exerce cette activité depuis 15 ans et s’approvisionne au Bénin et au Nigeria, état voisin du Bénin.  Pélagie n’a encore jamais bénéficié de crédit auprès de ALIDé. Dans le but d’agrandir son activité afin de mieux satisfaire la demande nombreuse des clients, Pélagie sollicite un premier prêt auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Pélagie V. was born on 31st August 1983 in Cotonou. She is a widow and has three children, all of whom are at school and in her care. Pélagie has lived alone with her children in Djeffa in the municipality of Sèmè-Podji for the past 20 years. She went to school up until secondary school level. In order to meet her needs, Pélagie has a business selling religious objects (prayer booklets, rosary beads, pictures etc..) as well as pots of flowers in front of the Catholic church in Djeffa. She has been carrying out this activity for 15 years and gets her supplies in Bénin and in the neighbouring country of Nigeria. Pélagie has never had a loan from ALIDé before, but with the aim of expanding her business in order to satisfy heavy customer demand more readily, she is applying for a first loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of religious objects and pots of flowers

loans.name: Idowu

texts.en: Idowu is 38 years old, married and blessed with two children. Her husband is a lecturer in the higher institution in Asaba, Delta State. Her children are excelling in their school. She sells groceries and foodstuffs at retail prices to her customers. She is doing well in her business but her greatest challenge is funds and she hopes to overcome this challenge. She hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 NIgerian naira to purchase more groceries to sell. She hopes to expand her business in the future. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Grocery store inventory

loans.name: Shamim's Group

texts.en:
Kaniz wants a loan to buy items (chairs, mirror) for her gent’s hair salon. Sugran wants a loan to buy video games for her family's game shop. 

Shamim is the wife of A. A.. She is also the group leader of the afore-mentioned ladies. They all live in a city called Lahore, a city famous in Pakistan for its historical places and its Punjabi foods. 

Shamim has a two-room brick house in which she has been living for the past 25 years. She has given birth to five children: four sons and one daughter. Her eldest son is twenty-eight years old; he couldn’t get an education because of the family's meager financial resources. He has decided to start his own business of cloth-selling so his other siblings can afford to go to school and get an education. He started this business when he turned twenty years old. 

Shamim also helps him by doing the embroidery on simple cloth which attracts the customers and it has become the source of his good earning. So she is applying for a loan to buy seasonal cloth and beads and colored thread to expand her son’s clothes-selling business.

loans.use: To purchase clothes and materials for cloth-selling business

loans.name: Leonza Marina

texts.es: Leonza Marina tiene muchas experiencias con financiamientos por lo que ha sido lo más satisfactorio para ella.  La actividad económica de Doña Leonza es venta de mercadería en general. Hace más de 6 años que inicio este negocio, la ubicación de su negocio es de manera ambulante, pues siempre le ha gustado trabajar de la forma más humilde pero con muchos sacrificios ha obtenido lo necesario. Ella solicita este financiamiento para capital de trabajo y así aplicar la inversión en pantalones, camisas, ropa interior, bolsas plásticas y calzado. El sueño de ella es ampliar su negocio.
texts.en:
Leonza Marina has a lot of experience with loans. They have been most satisfactory for her. Leonza sells general merchandise. She started the business over six years ago. She is a street vendor. She has always liked working in this most humble way. With a lot of sacrifices she has gotten what she needed. She is asking for this loan for working capital. She will invest in pants, shirts, underwear, plastic bags, and footwear. Her dream is to expand her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Welita

texts.en:
Welita M. is from the village of Bunawan. She is 32 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Welita owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from selling pigs. Welita has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP per month from these activities. She also sells ready-to-wear and cosmetics items, making a monthly net income of 2,000 PHP.
In 2009, Welita joined Kiva partner, PMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used as additional capital for her hog-raising business. This loan will be her first from PMPC.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: As additional capital for her hog-raising business

loans.name: Felicidad's Group

texts.en:
Felicidad S. is from the village of Song-Song. She is 32 years old. Felicidad is the group leader of a 9-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Felicidad S. Group.

Felicidad is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Felicidad owns & operates a transportation business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing motorcycle transport in the local community. Felicidad has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Felicidad joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Felicidad is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This will be the first loan taken out by Felicidad from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Kun

texts.en:
Kun S., 29, sells CDs, VCDs and refill gas from home, making US$5 each day in Kandal province. She is married and has two young children living at home to support. Her husband, Bou S., is on the private staff of a local company. He makes approximately US$8 every day.

Kun would like a loan of US$1,000 to set up a grocery store so that her income will increase daily.

loans.use: To set up a grocery store

loans.name: Mr. Chhin Sok Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan has ten people who live in Trapeang Kralaong village in Takeo province. They all will use their portion of the loan for different purposes that improve their standard of living. 

Mr. Chhin S. is a village bank president who was selected by the other members. He was born in 1951. He is a farmer who owns a small piece of the land to cultivate rice to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Bour Men, is a door-to-door broom seller. Since his wife’s business is going well she wants to expand. So to improve this business, Mr. Chhin S. is applying for a loan to buy more brooms for resale. He is a father of three children: one also sells brooms, while the other two attend the local public school.

loans.use: To buy more brooms for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy core ingredients for her meals and Claro recharge cards.

loans.name: Bryan

texts.en:
Bryan A. is from the town of Talibon. He is 32 years old. Bryan is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Bryan owns & operates a business venture in the food sector operating a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating a fishing boat to catch and sell assorted fish to the market. Bryan has been engaged in his business for over 6 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

Bryan joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Bryan is requesting a new loan of 3000 PHP which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his business and financially support his family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn T. is from the village of Manaoag. She is 50 years old, married and has 2 adult children. Marilyn owns & operates an agricultural business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. She has been engaged in this business for over 20 years and earns approximately 30,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2008, Marilyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. She is requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Marilyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Welington Carlos

texts.en:
Welington Carlos C. C. is 43 years old. He lives in Chillanes in the province of Bolivar. He has two children, who are ages 27 and 28. 

Welington is a member of the rural loan group ¨San Jose del Eden.¨ The group is located about an hour and a half from the town of San Jose del Tambo. The group consists of 20 members, the majority of whom work in agriculture.  

Welington also works in agriculture and raises animals. He does the buying and selling of his products in the nearby town of Matilde Esther.

He plans to use the loan for agricultural purposes and hopes that the loan will help him improve his crops. His goal is to keep progressing with his crops.

He likes to play sports in his free time.

loans.use: To grow crops

loans.name: Nuon's Group

texts.en:
Eight members are part of this village loan. Mrs. Nuon V., who was born in 1970, was selected as the village bank president by the group members. All members of this village loan live in Tuol Sankae village, Kandal province. With their loan, each member of this village bank hopes to increase his or her income to improve the living of their families.

Mrs. Nuon V. sells sand at home, while her husband, Mr. Khon Suy, who is 50 years old, works as a foreman worker. With the income from both of their occupations they are able to earn a small income to support the family. Mrs. Nuon V. will use the loan that she has asked for from AMK to buy more sand to sell. This couple has four children: one is a vehicle driver of goods, one is a construction worker, one is attending the local school,  while the other is 3 years old.

loans.use: To buy more sand to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Norjmoo

texts.en: Norjmoo A. is a 49 year-old widow who lives with her three children in Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. She and her children live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic home tent. Her youngest son attends a local secondary school. Norjmoo operates a variety of businesses in order to provide for her family. She has been operating a water hole since 2007. Her customers are usually neighboring households. During the summer, her oldest daughter runs the water hole while Norjmoo operates a construction business with help of her children. During the winter months, they go through the countryside selling a variety of products to supplement the family's income. Norjmoo hopes to built a stable and successful operation that can improve their family's standard of living. She is requesting a 300,000 MNT loan to purchase stationary and clothes to sell.

loans.use: To purchase stationary and clothes to sell

loans.name: Munhnasan

texts.en:
Munhnasan S. owns and operates a clothing production business in her town. She designs and produces a wide variety of clothing items. She started this business in 2004 and has gained much experience as a seamstress. Her business is very popular in her community and she has built a positive reputation amongst her customers. In the future, Munhnasan hopes to further grow her business and use her earnings to purchase a fence and house for her family. 

She is requesting an 400,000 MNT loan to purchase more fabrics and materials for her sewing business. 										
Munhnasan lives with her husband and two children in Arhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a "ger," a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent home, in a rented yard. Her son, age 18, attends university and her husband works as a salesman.

loans.use: To purchase more fabrics and materials for her sewing business

loans.name: Lubna

texts.en:
Lubna is a young wife and mother of two daughters and one son: Haya, Saja and Abdul Rahman, who are four, three and two years old, respectively, Lubna's husband runs an electronics store in Rafah, selling all kinds of home electronics.

Lubna's husband wanted to buy more goods to increase his sales and returns, so Lubna came to FATEN and asked for a $806.32 loan.

The store is located in the city center.  Having more goods to sell will increase the returns and improve the family's situation.

Lubna's husband appears in the picture here as she comes from a religious background and doesn't want her picture posted online.

Important information about this loan:

FATEN offers loan products that are designed to serve borrowers all over Palestine, including some religiously conservative areas. A key tenet of Islam is the prohibition of interest in the lending or accepting of money. This prohibition is based on the belief that money should be seen only as a medium of exchange and that it has no value in itself. FATEN has adapted the terms of this loan to fit the cultural context by attaching a 0% interest rate to the loan. In order to cover its costs, FATEN does charge a servicing fee. The amount you see fundraising includes both the principal loan and the loan servicing fees. As with all Kiva loans, you should expect to have your funds returned to you in accordance with the repayment schedule attached to this loan. For more information on lending in the Muslim world, please visit our FAQs.

loans.use: To purchase electrical goods to sell in the store

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en:
Margarita is married with two grown children and an 8-year-old daughter. She is a small business owner from Vinogradovo, Western Ukraine. Margarita sells men’s outer wear, lamps and chandeliers in the central marketplace of her home town. Her vending facility is located right in the centre of the market. There are few competitors with the same stock for sale which creates favorable conditions for the growth of Margarita’s business.  

Margarita has been in this sphere of trade for 10 years. Presently, she has 30,000 Grivnyas in turnover capital. Her gross income amounts to 12,000 Grivnyas. Monthly net profit is 3,000 Grivnyas. Margarita is requesting a loan of 7,000 Grivnyas to invest in increasing her working capital. She is hoping to add items to the selection of inventory she offers for sale in her kiosk. Margarita is an ambitious entrepreneur. She doesn’t want to stop where she is at. She is hoping to open an additional vending location in the nearest future thus expanding her business even further.

loans.use: to increase her working capital

loans.name: El Progreso De Tahuantinsuyo Group

texts.es:
MARIA C. SARMIENTO, residente D. la zona D. Independencia, conviviente, D. 52 años D. edad y con una simpatía que la caracteriza.
La Sra. María, hace diez años y todos los días desD. muy temprano se dedica a atender su negocio D. venta D. comida rápida, el cual inició con mucho sacrificio; tenia la experiencia D. su mama quien hacia muchos años también vendía comida; pero fue mas por un amiga quien vendía muy bien y veía que ese negocio la daba buena rentabilidad, con el esfuerzo D. su gran esfuerzo diario D. trabajo ha podido solventar los gastos D. su familia, su mayor anhelo comprar mas productos para surtir mas su negocio y luego abrir una bodega en su domicilio. 
El préstamo solicitado lo invertirá en la compra D. mercadería para su negocio (cerveza).

Hoy en día, integra la ALCOM “EL PROGRESO D. TAHUANTINSUYO”, es la presidenta del grupo, y junto a 08 emprendedores integrantes luchan y se apoyan D. pospréstamos que obtienen D. EDAPROSPO para hacer crecer sus negocios y salir adelante.
texts.en:
52-year old María C. Sarmiento lives with her husband in the neighbourhood of Independencia. She is known for her friendly personality.

For the last ten years María has earned her living selling fast food. She does this every day from early in the morning. It took a lot of sacrifice to get the business going, but she drew on her mother’s experience as she also used to sell fast food. However, it was a friend in the same line of work who told María that such a business would be profitable. Daily hard work has meant that she has been able to pay for the family’s expenses. Her greatest wish is to buy more stock for her business and also to open a store in her home.

María will use the loan to buy more merchandise for her business (beer for example).

She is the president of the Alcom “El Progreso D. Tahuantinsuyo”. She and the other eight members work together to pay off the loans obtained through Kiva partner EDAPROSPO to expand their businesses and get ahead in life.

loans.use: to buy merchandise for her business

loans.name: Angel Eugenio

texts.es:
En la ciudadela nueva california de la ciudad de Portoviejo, capital de Manabí conocida desde hace muchos años  como la ciudad de los reales tamarindos, se reúnen cada quince días  las socias del Banco Comunal Nueva Jerusalén.
 
Aquí conocimos a Ángel él tiene 24  años de edad, está casado y fruto de esta relación tiene dos hijos de 6 y 11 años los mismos que están en la escuela. Su mujer es comerciante.

Se dedica a la venta de periódicos y revistas, tiene un puesto en las calles América y AV. Manabí en la ciudad de Portoviejo, trabaja todos los días desde 06h00 hasta las 12h00. Nos cuenta que lleva varios años que se dedica a esta actividad y que ha ido creciendo poco a poco, ahora espera invertir este crédito en ropa para aprovechar la temporada que las personas compran mucho de estos productos.

Este crédito lo va a invertir para ir a Guayaquil a  comprar ropa, pantalones, camisas, camisetas, etc. lleva en el Banco Comunal tres ciclos y le gusta por la rapidez para conseguir los créditos. Su sueño es tener su casa propia ya que donde vive es arrendado.
texts.en:
The members of the Communal Bank of Nueva Jerusalén meet every fifteen days in the Nueva California neighborhood of the city of Portoviejo. Portoviejo is the capital of Manabí Province and has been known for years as the city of the Royal Tamarind Trees.

This is where we met 24-year-old Ángel. He is a married and has two children from this relationship, ages six and eleven. Both of his children are in school and his wife is a shopkeeper.
 
He works selling newspapers and magazines at a stand in Portoviejo, located at the intersection of Calle América and Avenida Manabí. He works every day from 6 to 12. He told us that he's been doing this job for several years now and that he has grown his business bit by bit. He would like to use this loan to purchase clothing in order to take advantage of the fact that people are buying lots of clothing right now.

He will use this loan to travel to Guayaquil to buy clothes such as pants, shirts, undershirts etc. He has participated in three funding cycles with the Communal Bank. He appreciates how quickly he can obtain loans through the bank. His dream is to own his own house as he is currently renting.

loans.use: Purchase of pants, shirts, undershirts etc.

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida lives in the village of Anoushayan in the Shirak region of Armenia.  She is the proud mother of three children: a thirteen year old son, sixteen and seventeen year old daughters.  Aida has a college education.  With her husband they have been working on the family farm for over twenty years.  

Aida considers herself to be a hard working sincere person and would like to grow her business.  She also helps relatives living in the town of Artik with produce from her farm.  She is looking for a loan to purchase additional calves.  According to her business plan, this investment will increase the family income by around twenty five percent.  In additional to growing the family business she dreams of saving enough money for her children to go to college.  Currently her oldest daughter is studying at university.  Aida enjoys living in Anoushayan close to her relatives and good friends.

loans.use: To purchase calves.

loans.name: Khairi

texts.en:
Khairi is a 34-year-old man from Tulkarem City and works as an employee of the Palestinian Academy for Security Sciences. Khairi is one of four brothers.  He is engaged, with his wedding planned for next summer.

He requested a loan from Kiva partner FATEN to cover his wedding expenses, which include the cost of booking the wedding hall and other expenses.

Khairi appears in the picture at FATEN's office.

loans.use: Cover wedding expenses

loans.name: Sonia Alba Lina

texts.es:
Sonia de 43 años, es una mujer trabajadora que por buenas decisiones es una microempresaria. Aunque esta actualmente separada ella continua trabajando. 

El inicio de su negocio fue con la venta de helados y bolos (refrescos congelados que los vacían en fundas) frente a una escuela. Poco a poco con la buena administración que le dio al dinero que ganaba comenzó a comprar víveres para vender comida y tambien con venta de bebidas. En la actualidad trabaja desde las 06:30am hasta las 21h30pm vendiendo comidas y tiene un negocio de bebidas (aparece en la foto). 

Tiene muchas aspiraciones con su negocio por eso quiere continuar trabajando y comprar con el préstamo víveres y recargas celulares para tener un ingreso adicional.
texts.en:
Sonia is 43 years old and she is a hard working woman and following some sound decisions she is now a small business owner. And although she recently became separated she still keeps up her business. 

She started out selling icecreams and bolos (frozen soft drinks that have been poured in bags) in front of a school. Through sound business administration and with time she earns enough money to purchase ingredients to prepare foods and to sell drinks. Currently she works from 6:30am to 9:30pm selling foods and drinks (the business is shown in the photo). 

She aspires to accomplish many things through her business, which is why she wants to keep working. The loan will be used to purchase ingredients and prepaid cell phone cards as an additional source of income.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise, prepaid cell phone cards, and soft drinks.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in computer literacy training program

loans.name: Samar

texts.en:
Samar is a 21-year-old wife and the mother of one daughter and one son. Her husband, Bilal, is a taxi driver in the city of Rafah in Gaza Strip. Samar's husband has been a taxi driver for five years. His car needs urgent maintenance. Samar took out a loan from FATEN as her husband can't cover the expenses all at once, and it would be easier to pay back on a monthly basis.

Samar's husband appears in the picture here as Samar is a conservative woman.

loans.use: For urgent maintenance work on a taxi

loans.name: Eduardo Atilio

texts.es: El prestatario es padre soltero sus hijos son mayores D. edad y trabajan D. manera independiente su pareja viajo al extranjero a trabajar y no regreso nunca mas, el trabajaba en una empresa D. L. cual fue despedido y con su indemnización adquirió su unidad D. transporte con L. cual obtiene ingresos para su manutencion; Ahora se dedica al servicio D. taxi y se encuentra asociado a L. empresa Latino Tour cuenta con un buen nivel D. ingresos no tiene endeudamiento vive en casa D. un familiar esta solicitando el prestamos para darle mantenimiento a su vehiculo tiene buenas referencias personales,su sueño es seguir adquiriendo nuevas unidades D. transportes y mejorar sus ingresos, es por ello que se propone el crédito.
texts.en: The borrower is a single father who works independently and whose children are already grown up. His partner travelled abroad to work and will not return. He worked for a company and was laid off. With his severance package he purchased a vehicle which is how he earns money for its maintenance. He now works as a taxi driver and is associated with a company called Latino Tour. He earns a decent income, has no debt, and lives in the home of a relative. He is requesting the loan to service his vehicle. He has good personal references and his dream is to continue acquiring new vehicle and improve his income.

loans.use: maintenance for his vehicle

loans.name: Theara

texts.en:
Mrs. Theara S. (in the photo with her loom) and her husband, Mr. Sovan Norn, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have one son and two daughters. Two are in school and the other one is still young.  

Theara is a weaver, while her husband is fisherman and farmer. She is requesting a loan of $300 to purchase weaving materials for continuing her business.

loans.use: To purchase weaving materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok S. O. is a 41-year-old married woman who earns a daily profit by working as a high schoO. teacher in the Baray district of Kompong Tom province. She has over ten years of experience in this sector and earns a formal salary every month. In order to help cover the family expenses, her husband works as a foreman of construction workers in the mobile place, where he gets a daily income averaging $5.20 per day. 

Sok S. O. will use her loan to buy a plot of land which is near her house so that she can grow a rice crop or enlarge her house. With the rest of the loan, she will buy construction tools to assist her husband's business. Sok S. O. has only one child who is still studying.

loans.use: to buy a plot of land to grow crops or enlarge her house

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more cassava to process into gari for resale.

loans.name: Jerendi's Group

texts.en:
Jerendi K. is the leader of this group. She is 48 and, unfortunately, she is a widow. She has raised two sons and a daughter. Her first son works in construction in Bishkek, the second works in Kazakhstan, the daughter is married and lives separately with her family. Five years ago, with the initial investment of 10000 soms, Jerendi bought two calves for breeding. Currently, to meet her needs, she sells 5-6 liters (10 soms per liter) of milk every day. In this way she earns about 3000 soms per month. With the loan, she wants to purchase five farm animals for breeding. In the future Jerendi wishes to expand her business to be able to financially support her children. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase five farm animals

loans.name: Somoye

texts.en:
Somoe, a married woman with four children, owns the family home that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. For the past 10 years, Somoe has operated a bakery business, making and selling bread at the market to her neighbours and passersby. She also sells palm leaves. Somoe faces the major challenge of seasonality, as during the rainy season she experiences low customer turnout.

Having joined Yehu to access loans to boost her business, Somoe is requesting a loan of KES 15,000 to expand her business, purchase palm leaves, sacks of rice, sugar and yeast for her bakery. She dreams of becoming a big supplier in the future.

loans.use: to expand her business, purchase palm leaves, sacks of rice, sugar and yeast for her bakery.

loans.name: Marcela

texts.es: Marcela de 52 años, está casada con Marcos, de 61 años. Ambos tienen 3 hijos, pero solo viven con uno de ellos: Omar de 25 años. Los tres como una gran familia, viven en su casa propia ubicada en la localidad de Puente Paucartambo (selva central peruana). Como mujer trabajadora ella apoya a su esposo en los gastos del hogar. Pues la agricultura, actividad de su esposo,  les proporcionan lo necesario para poder sobrevivir: “techo y comida”. Pero con una mirada emprendedora; Marcela nos comenta que  hace 7 años abrió una pequeña tienda de comestibles, donde vende productos de primera necesidad. Desde las primeras horas del día, los habitantes de la localidad visitan su tienda, pues ellos saben lo surtida que se mantiene. Ya en sus tiempos libres, de dedica a la costura, todos la conocen y, constantemente la buscan para ofrecerle trabajo. Además comenta que en tiempos de campaña agrícola se dedica a la compra y venta de café; comprando a los agricultores cada lata de café secado y preparado a S/. 80 soles, luego revendiendo la lata a una empresa reconocida a S/. 88 soles cada una, obteniendo un dinero extra. “Tengo que aprovechar la campaña”, afirma. Los clientes que ganó, le izó  aumentar sus ventas; es por ello que para más adelante ella desea comprarse una máquina industrial, con la que está segura podrá cocer con mayor facilidad y rapidez.   Ella pertenece al banco comunal “Luz del Futuro”, y este es el   sexto crédito con MFP, donde espera un pequeño préstamo para cumplir sus objetivos. Por otro lado se compromete una vez más a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas, como en anteriores créditos que tuvo. Además le agrada ser parte de su banco comunal porque todos sus integrantes son personas responsables y muy solidarias. Marcela, de obtener su apoyo; invertirá el dinero solicitado en la compra de café, pues están en campaña de cosecha.
texts.en: 52-year-old Marcela is married to 61-year-old Marcos.  They have 3 children, but only live with one of them: 25-year-old Omar.  The three are like a big family. They live in their own home located in the town of Puente Paucartambo (Peruvian central jungle). As a working woman, she helps her husband with the household expenses.  Agriculture, her husband’s business, provides the necessary for survival “food and shelter”.  But, with an entrepreneurial air, Marcela told us that 7 years ago she opened a small food store, where she sells basic goods.  From the early hours of the morning, the inhabitants of her town visit the store, since they know the level of stock she maintains. In her free time, she sews. Everyone knows her and they are constantly seeking her out to offer her work. In addition, she says that in the harvest season she buys and sells coffee – buying tins of dried coffee from agricultural producers for .80 New Peruvian Soles and reselling them at a profit to a recognized company for .88 New Peruvian Soles. “I have to take advantage of the harvest,” she affirms.  The customers she has gained caused her to increase her sales, which is why in the future she wants to buy herself an industrial machine with which she is sure she will be able to sew easier and faster.  She belongs to the communal bank “Luz del Future” “(Light of the Future) and this is her sixth loan with MFP, where she is waiting for a small loan so that she can reach her goals.  Moreover, she promises once again to make all her payments, as was the case with her previous loans.  In addition, she is grateful to be part of a communal bank, because all the members are responsible and supportive people. Marcela, having obtained your support, will invest the requested loan in the purchase of coffee, since they are in harvest season.

loans.use: to buy coffee.

loans.name: Mirgul's Group

texts.en:
Mirgul is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Tokmok, a small town near to Bishkek (the capital of Kyrgyzstan). She is 33 and married to soldier.  Together with her husband she brings up two children, both of whom study at school. In order to earn additional money to meet their daily needs, the family eight years ago with an initial investment of 5000 soms rented a canteen and started to sell food.  At the moment the family’s monthly profit from this business is 15000 soms. Mirgul applied for the loan because she needs additional money to purchase foodstuffs and various products for preparing food in the canteen.  In the future with money gained from the business Mirgul wants to purchase a vehicle for the family.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year.
