Yimmy is a corn, rice and broad bean farmer.  He buys his supplies in Comercial Peña and sells at the Ventanas wholesale market.

He is asking for the loan to plant corn and rice, to buy farming supplies and fertilizer for his crops.  Help from the loan will help him economically to meet his needs.  His dream is to improve his family’s economic condition.

He enjoys reading and studying.

loans.use: to buy farming supplies and fertilizer.

loans.name: Amiran

texts.en:
Amiran is from the village of Manavi in the Kakheti Region. He is 49 years old and lives with his wife Maya and mother in law, who is retired. 

Amiran has some health problems and receives relevant social assistance from the government, but still he is actively involved in operations at the family owned dairy farm. Amiran and Maya own 3 milk cows. They sell yogurt, cheese and milk in their and nearby villages. They have loyal customers as their dairy products are well-known by good quality. The family has 30 years experience in dairy farming.

Amiran has  requested a loan to purchase  2 additional milk cows. The family will be able to sell approximately 60% more dairy products. This will have a positive impact on the family’s income. 

Amiran and Maya plan to reinvest the expected increase in income in further expansion of the dairy farm.

loans.use: to purchase 2 milk cows for the dairy farm

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida is 50 years old.  She is engaged in an aluminum and glass supplies business, earning PHP 10,000 monthly. She offers sliding windows and sliding doors. Through this business, she is giving employment to her relatives by giving them work in the business.  

In her first year of operation, she encountered difficulties maintaining the business due to the high cost of schooling for her youngest child.

Zenaida is requesting a loan amount of PHP 25,000 to buy supplies such as glass and other metals used in making sliding windows and doors. She hopes that she can expand her venture in manufacturing. This thing might be a bit difficult for her, but with strong determination in life, Zenaida believes that she can do it with the help of God.

loans.use: buy supplies to make windows and doors

loans.name: Omar De La Concepcion

texts.es: El señor  Omar , es habitante del municipio de Ticuantepe  , junto a su esposa e hijos , los planes hacia un futuro es mejorar las condiciones de vida , para brindarles un mejor bienestar a su hijos , don Omar desde hace vaR. años labora en una casa privada , la mayor dificultad que se le presenta es que no puede realizar de una sola vez la construcción de un cuarto ya que la casa donde habitan es muy pequeña  y casi esta todo junto por los espacios tan chiquitos ;   que si logra poner unos muebles no tiene espacio para caminar. El quiere el financiamiento para la compra de materiales de construcción. Agradece Afodenic que atrávez de fondo Kiva  el apoyo que le brinda a las personas de bajos recursos para que logren realizar sus sueños de tener una vivienda digna.
texts.en:
Sr. Omar is a resident of the town of Ticuantepe and lives with his wife and children. His plans for the future are to improve his living conditions and provide a better state of well-being for his children. For several years, Don Omar has worked for a private residence. His greatest difficulty has been not being able to make a one-time purchase of construction materials so that he can build a room in his house because right now it is very small. Due to the limited space, almost everything is occupied. There is hardly enough space to walk around and no room for additional furniture.

Omar needs this loan to buy construction materials. He is grateful to AFODENIC for providing Kiva funds. The support provided to people with limited resources enables them to achieve their dreams, such as having a decent home.

loans.use: to buy construction materials for building a room.

loans.name: Ma. Rolenda

texts.en:
Ma. Rolenda is 37 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with six children. 

Ma. Rolenda has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks, and beverages. She has had this business for six years. She has requested a loan for PHP 6,000 to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages for her shop.

Ma. Rolenda has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. In the future, Ma. Rolenda hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages for her store.

loans.name: Gregory  Musyoki

texts.en:
Gregory Musyoki is 46 years old and married to Pauline, a business lady. Together they have two kids. His primary business is construction. He has been in the sector for the past three years. His monthly income from the business is 30,000 KES.


  This is his fourth loan with KADET.His previous loans were repaid successfully .The loan will help him buy construction materials. The anticipated profits will help pay fees for his children. His dream is to own a residential building.

loans.use: Buy  blocks and other construction materials.

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Marissa is 37 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 2 children. Marissa has a retail shop that sells canned goods, snacks, beverages and rice by the kilogram. She has had this business for 10 years. She has requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, snacks and rice to sell.

Marissa is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Marissa hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and rice to sell

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en: Emmanuel, 22 years old and single, lives in the Philippines where he has operated a shop selling green and yellow bananas for the past five years. A new member of HSPFI, Emmanuel has requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy more bananas to sell, and in the future hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy green & yellow bananas to sell.

loans.name: Rasmiah

texts.en:
Rasmiah and her husband Rashad have started a small business in a storage room in their house mixing detergents and then selling them. 

Rashad also works as a driving teacher so they can support their family that includes five children. Now they want to buy more raw materials that are used in manufacturing these cleaning products, so Rasmiah has decided to apply for a loan under her name to be able to do that.

Because Rasmiah is a conservative person, her husband Rashad has agreed to be in the photo.

loans.use: to buy more raw materials that are used in manufacturing cleaning products.

loans.name: Odbayar

texts.en:
Mr. Odbayar, 26, is a taxi driver and runs his taxi business around the districts of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He has been doing the taxi service for 6 years and it is his main income source. Lately, his car has started to have some breaks and is becoming dangerous to serve the customers. Therefore he needs to change some parts and some sections. It will be good for his business earnings if he could make repairs before this winter. 

The loan Odbayar is requesting will be used to purchase some new spare-parts for his taxi car and make a repairs to it.

loans.use: To purchase spare-parts for his taxi car

loans.name: María Isaura

texts.es:
Comprar un vehículo para transportar los productos de su panadería es el sueño de María Isaura quien desde hace cuatro años tiene una panadería en Medellín, sus panes son apetecidos en el sector debido a su sabor y frescura. 

Actualmente esta emprendedora necesita de un préstamo para comprar insumos en mayores cantidades lo que le permitirá comprarlos a menor precio para incrementar sus ganancias.
texts.en: To be able to purchase a vehicle to transport her bakery goods is Maria's dream.  For 4 years she has had a bakery in Medellin,  where her delicious and freshly baked breads and pastries are in great demand.   This enterprising businesswoman is requesting the loan to purchase ingredients in greater quantities and at lower prices, which will enable her to increase her earnings.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients for her bakery in greater quantities and at lower prices.

loans.name: Lisceth Margarita

texts.es:
Lisceth Margarita tiene 19 años de edad es casada tiene un hijo, vive con el esposo, madre y el hijo de un año de edad en Guaranda Sector Cuatro Esquinas Provincia de Bolívar.
LA VRC Cuatro Esquinas Central está formada por 12 socios que pertenecen al sector cuatro esquinas, los socios se dedican a diferentes actividades como son agricultura, crianza de animales, comercio y otros.
Lisceth se dedica a la crianza de animales (pollos, cerdos) además se dedica a los estudios.
Las compras y las ventas lo realizan en Guaranda.
Solicita el crédito para la compra de animales y balanceado.
Con la ayuda del crédito le ayudará a mejorar los ingresos y situación de vida.
El sueño es poder terminar los estudios, tener un título profesional y tener un trabajo estable.
No se le ha presentado ningún tipo de problema. En los tiempos libres le gusta practicar el deporte como el básquet le gusta bailar, pasear y escuchar música, disfrutar de las fiestas del carnaval, San José, Navidad.
texts.en:
Lisceth Margarita is 19 years old, married with a child, lives with her husband, mother and 1 year old child in the Cuatro Esquinas [Four Corners] sector of Guaranda, in the Province of Bolivar.

The VCR Cuatro Esquinas Central is made up of 12 members who live in the Cuatro Esquinas sector. The members work in different businesses such as agriculture, breeding of animals, trade and others. 

Lisceth works growing animals (chickens and pigs) and she is also a student. She buys and sells in Guaranda. She is asking for a loan to buy animals and animal feed. The loan will help to increase her earnings and improve her way of life.

Her dream is to be able to finish her studies, to have a professional degree, and to have a stable job. She has never had any problems. In her free time she likes to play sports such as basketball, she likes to dance, she enjoys listening to music, and she enjoys the festivities of Carnival, San José and Christmas.

loans.use: to buy animals and animal feed

loans.name: Rene

texts.es:
Rene tiene 48 años de edad, es una persona trabajadora. Él vive en la provincia Quillacollo del departamento de Cochabamba, genera ingresos para sostener a su familia, vendiendo leche cruda de vaca a los vecinos de su zona y su esposa es quien elabora y vende los deliciosos chorizos paceños.
Rene  vive  con su familia, tiene a su cuidado 4 hijos, necesita el préstamo para comprar forraje para su ganado vacuno y haga frente a la escases de alimento que existe en su localidad y así pueda seguir alimentando a su ganado hasta que la situación mejore. 
Rene entre sus planes futuros planea sacar un nuevo préstamo edificar establos.
texts.en:
Rene is 48 years old and a hard-working person.  He lives in Quillacollo province, in Cochabamba department.  He makes income to support his family by selling raw cows' milk to his neighbors.  His wife makes and sells delicious La Paz chorizo.

Rene lives with his family and has four children in his care.  He needs this loan to buy fodder for his cows and thereby deal with the problem of a scarcity of feed that exists in his town.  This will enable him to continue feeding his cows until the situation improves.

Rene's future plans include taking out another loan to build some stables.

loans.use: to buy fodder for his cows

loans.name: Akot

texts.en:
Akot is  40 years old, married, and has five children, three of whom attend in school. She has a food stall in Bor, South Sudan, which she has been doing for two years.

Akot is requesting a loan through BRAC South Sudan, which she will use  to purchase beans, vegetables and onions. She will use her extra income from this loan to pay the school fees of her children.

loans.use: to purchase beans, vegetables and onions to sell.

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
Theresa lives in West Point. She is 46 years old, married, and a university student. For five years now, Theresa has been involved in the sales of fashion clothes. Most interestingly, she has many customers because she is the only one who sells quality fashion clothes in her community.

Theresa is requesting a loan to buy more fashion clothes (blouses, jeans, trousers, and shirts) and many other items for her business. She plans to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more fashion clothes (blouses, jeans, trouser, and shirts) and many items for her business.

loans.name: Monicah

texts.en:
Monicah is a married woman. She has a son who is 7 years old. She describes herself to be honest and God-fearing. 

Monicah operates a butcher shop where she sells meat. She has been involved in this business for five years. Her business is located near a busy market and her primary customers are repeat and new. She describes her biggest business challenge as the increase in the price of the meat sometimes. 

She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more meat.

loans.use: to buy more meat.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary M. buys fresh fish from the local fisherman and processes them by smoking and then selling them at the market centers in the nearby towns and villages. She has two fish processing equipments and wants to purchase a third one due to the rapid expansion of her business activities. She is a regular participant on the Kraban Support Foundation 's skills training program known as TEACH. She has a simple business plan. She needs a loan of $725 from KIVA to erect a third 'chorkor smoker', a locally manufactured fish processing equipment.

loans.use: A Fish Processing Machine called Chorkor Smoker

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
Dolores lives in a tiny rural village in Los Alcarrizos yet business at her small store is very busy. Her store supplies the day-to-day necessities for everyone in her village since traditional grocery stores are too far away and too expensive for many people in her community. Her store, called a colmadito, is an 8-square-foot wooden building on the siD. of the road that sells household items, non-perishable food, and refrigerated products. This new loan will help her to purchase more merchandise in high-demand to adequately proviD. for her growing customer base. The increase in profits will help Dolores improve the standard of living for her two children, ages 10 and 18.

NOTE: Dolores is a member of the group called "La Fe" (Faith), along with four other entrepreneurs. They will be accountable to one another for paying back this loan of $750. This group-lending method requires group members to help one another throughout the loan repayment process. Loans are paid back as a group. If one person is deficient on their loan, the group must make up the difference. Everyone in Dolores’ group has gone through Esperanza's training and shown themselves to be responsible and committed to paying back their loan in order to proviD. for their families.

loans.use: Restock dairy products, household merchandise, beverages, and staples such as rice, beans, and bread

loans.name: Ramón

texts.en:
Ramon is a very responsible and hard working man. He is married and has three children. Before this employment, he used to sell mobile phones but made little profit from it.

He had always wanted to start a hardware store but he didn't have enough money. So he started saving and when he had a little capital he bought some merchandise and started selling it in flea markets, laying his products over a cloth on the ground.

His knowledge of this type of business and his good work have allowed him to grow. He has managed to rent a small shop and increase his sales.

At the moment, Ramon needs a loan of $925 which he will use to purchase more merchandise and continue growing the business. He is offering to pay back the loan in 3 to 6 months. With your help you can improve the life of this family and contribute to the growth of this business. Don't think twice about it, make your mind to support him!

Translated from Spanish by Luis López Martinelli, Kiva Volunteer.


Ramón es un hombre muy trabajador y responsable, es casado y tiene tres hijos, antes él se dedicaba a la venta de teléfonos celulares pero obtenía muy pocas ganancias, siempre había querido iniciar una ferretería pero no contaba con los recursos suficientes para invertir en este tipo de negocio, empezó a ahorrar y cuando juntó un poco de capital compró algo de mercancía y se fue a venderla en los tianguis, extendiendo sus productos en una manta en el suelo. Sus conocimientos en este tipo de negocio y su buen trabajo le han permitido crecer, ahora ha conseguido tener un pequeño local e incrementar sus ventas.

En estos momentos, Ramón necesita un préstamo por $ 925 dólares que utilizará en la compra de mercancía para continuar creciendo con su negocio, él ofrece devolver esta cantidad en un lapso de 3 a 6 meses. Con tu ayuda puedes mejorar la vida de esta familia y contribuir al crecimiento de su negocio, no lo pienses más y decídete a apoyarlo.

loans.use: Purchasing merchandise

loans.name: Musa

texts.en:
This loan for Musu M. was orginally posted for $1050 with a default loan term of 1 month. The loan term should have been 12 months. SMT apologizes for this error. The loan was disbursed as scheduled and her first payment made. SMT is now reposting the loan for the balance of 11 months of the original term at $975. SMT appreciates your patience as we continue to provide microcredit services to the economically active poor of Sierra Leone.

Musu M., a 31 year old mother of four children is a very dynamic woman. Musu and her husband learned soap-making skills in one of the local skills training centers. She manages a soap production business with eight employees and her husband assists with selling the product in the remote villages of Sierra Leone. The soap is made out of palm oil, caustic soda and some colors. Musu can produce more than 2,000 pieces of soap a week and distributes them to retailers in various villages. It takes a week to complete the selling and then her husband collects the cash for another round of production. This means Musu has to wait for more than a week before she can produce more soap. Musu will use the loan funds for more raw materials to ensure flow of production without waiting for sales to be completed.

loans.use: purchase raw materials to make soap

loans.name: Ven

texts.en: Mrs. Ven C., 46, is married with 3 children. One is a mechanic, one is a student and the other is married and lives away from home. Her husband works as a construction worker, earning $2.50 a day. Ven C. is currently a housewife, but in the future she would like to run a shop selling beef soup and Chinese noodles.

loans.use: to repair house

loans.name: Pablina

texts.en:
Sra. Pablina is a widowed 52-year-old with four children. The two older children live with her and attend college, for which Paulina has taken responsibility of paying. The family has a small home-based kiosk, located across from the health center of the city. With much effort, Pablina and her family have maintained the store for 12 years. When her husband died, she had to become able to fully support herself and her children, and therefore became further dedicated to improving her business. For example, over time, she added new products for sale, including cleaning supplies such as detergent, deodorant, fabric softener and soap. 
Pablina starts work early in the morning, and, twice a week, makes a trip to Clorinda, Rca. Argentina, where she buys the products she sells in her store. According to Pablina's experience, it is possible to buy products for cheaper in Clorinda. 
Pablina’s business has been growing since the opening of the store. Also her clientele has grown, and, as a result, she needs to buy a greater quantity and variety of products, including sugar, flour, rice, noodles, oil, herbs, and other articles. To be able to purchase the additional products, and to make her business more profitable, Pablina is asking for a loan of US$225.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise (sugar, rice, noodles, herbs, eggs, etc.) for sale

loans.name: Yoyoh

texts.en: Yoyoh, 36 years old, is the mother of a child aged 16. After she became a member of MBK, she began selling meatballs. She usually earns about US$ 5 per day and that is barely enough for her daily needs. Her husband, O., also sells meatballs, going around to various places to offer his meatballs for sale. Yoyoh is requesting a loan of US$ 75 to expand her meatball business and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her little meatball business

loans.name: Seferina

texts.es:
Due to her her dire financial situation, Seferina was one of the first women to work in a stand at the AAHH Laura Caller Market. Thanks to her efforts she was able to provide higher education for her 6 children, build her own house and open a small restaurant.

She has passed on this determination to her children. Her youngest son being an example of that. He works at the stand in his spare time in order to pay for medical school.

Seferina's goal is to be able to expand and stock her restaurant in order to make this her only business.

Translated from the Spanish by Libertad Leal, Kiva volunteer.

Fue una de las primeras mujeres que trabajó en el mercado del AAHH Laura Caller, y es que la urgencia de dinero fue grande. Debido a su esfuerzo, Seferina pudo darles educación superior a sus 6 hijos, construir su casa y poder poner un pequeño restaurante.

Este empeño ha sido transmitido a sus hijos, ejemplo de ello es el menor de sus hijos quien trabaja en sus ratos libres en el puesto para poder pagar sus estudios de Medicina.

La meta de Seferina es poder ampliar y surtir su restaurante para solo dedicarse a este negocio.

loans.use: To expand her restaurant business

loans.name: Jagatha Maiya

texts.en:
Jagatha Maiya D. lives in Chappagaun village. Chappagaun village is located in Lalitpur district. Most of the people in this region are engaged in farming. Mrs. D. lives in a single family home with her husband and two sons. Her husband Mr. Narandra D. is a taxi driver and drives his taxi in Kathmandu village. Her older son is in grade 5 and younger son is in pre-primary school.

Mrs. D. undertakes mushroom farming. She took 6 months of training in this work. She sells her product in the local market. People also come to her place and buy mushrooms from her. The demand for mushrooms is increasing in that area so Mrs. D. is requesting her 2nd term loan of Rs15000 to buy fertilizers and mushroom seeds for her work.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and mushrooms for her work

loans.name: Kiyinki B1 South A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Halima N.. She is currently in the business of clothing sales and is requesting a loan to purchase more clothes to sell. Halima is 30 years old and is single. Each week, Halima makes approximately UGX 20000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to re-invest in her business. Halima has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 150000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Halima is joined in her small group by Halima K., Sylvia Nbabazi, Fatuma N., and Rose N.. Halima K. has a business selling shoes and wants to purchase shoes in bulk. Sylvia Nbabazi is currently operating a business selling clothes and wants a loan to add more business. Fatuma N. operates a retail shop business and wants to add more commodities. Rose N. is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan to purchase a fridge.

loans.use: To increase inventory in clothing business

loans.name: Daouda

texts.fr:
Mr. Daouda Sen is a young man who left his native village two years ago to make his life in the big city of Thiès. To do this, he started a business of grocery trading with rental of a site for which he pays 15,000 francs CFA per month. This business has been going very well for him and he would like support to strengthen his merchandise stock.

Translated from French by Liana Bianchi, Kiva Volunteer.

Mr Daouda Sen est un jeune garçon qui a quitté son village natal depuis deux années pour gagner sa vie dans la grande ville de Thiès. Pour cela, il a embrassé le métier de commerce d’alimentation avec la location d’un local qu’il paye 15 000 FCFA par mois. Cette activité lui va très bien et il voudrait un appui pour renforcer ses stocks de marchandises.

loans.use: Strengthening his merchandise stock

loans.name: Suzy

texts.en:
Mambo from Mwanza, Tanzania! This is 40 year-old Suzy I.. She is married, and has three children between the ages of 7 and 17. She also has one other dependent. In 2004, Suzy established her tailoring and grains business. She is assisted by her two employees. Suzy requires a loan in order to purchase stocks of cloth and grain in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets. The lack of tangible collateral assets means they are deemed not-creditworthy by financial institutions, restricting access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extends a loan to her, then leases back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase stocks of cloth and grain in bulk.

loans.name: Tiba

texts.en: Hello from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 39 year-old Tiba Nasoro.  She is widowed, and has two children ages 10 and 15. In 2006, Tiba established her bar business. Tiba has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan in order to purchase additional stock including beer and soft drinks. She thanks you for your support. Tiba's bar is a good place to chill with a beer if you manage to finish work early on a Friday afternoon. It’s the kind of place where you kick back on a plastic chair under a tree, with a local beer in hand, the aroma of roasting ‘mishikaki’  (kebabs made on an open fire) wafting around you, and talk to anyone and everyone who happens to wander by.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of beer and soft drinks in bulk.

loans.name: Sylvestre

texts.fr:
Sylvestre S. is 32 years old, married, and the father of five children, who are all in school. He has been a tailor for over five years in Assahoun, a village located about 50 km from Lomé, the Togolese capital. In the photo, Mr. S. is the person in the middle dressed in a white shirt. He wishes to use this loan to acquire a sewing machine and some fabrics for resale to customers. This will enable him to satisfy customer demands better. The gains from his business will allow Mr. S. to meet family needs.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Sylvestre S. est âgé de 32 ans, marié et père de 5 enfants tous à l’école. Il est tailleur depuis plus de 5 ans à Assahoun, un village situé à environ 50 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Dans la photo, monsieur S. est la personne se trouvant au milieu et vêtu en chemise blanche. Il souhaite par ce crédit acquérir une machine à coudre et des tissus pour la revente aux clients. Ce qui lui permettra de mieux satisfaire la demande de ses clients. Les gains issus de son activité permettront à monsieur S. de faire face aux besoins de sa famille.

loans.use: To acquire a sewing machine and some fabrics for resale to customers

loans.name: Komla

texts.fr:
Komla D. is 28 years old, is married and a father of a child. To earn money he operates a spare parts shop on two wheels in Avétonou, a village located approximately 100 kilometers from Lome, the Togolese capital. With this credit, his second from FECECAV, he would like to build the supplies for his shop in order to meet the requests from his customers. Specifically, he wwould like to buy and resell motor bike parts imported from Nigeria. With the improvement of his activity, he can better provide for the needs of his child and thus take part in the development of his community.

Translated from French by Ivana Kostic, Kiva Translator

Komla D. est âgé de 28 ans, marié et père d’un enfant. Pour gagner de l’argent il opère une boutique des pièces détachées à deux roues à Avétonou, un village situé à environ 100 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale Togolaise. Avec ce crédit, son deuxième de FECECAV, il souhaite augmenter le stock de sa boutique pour répondre aux demandes de ses clients. Spécifiquement, il veut acheter les pièces moto généralement importées du Nigeria pour revendre. Avec l’amélioration de son activité, il peut mieux subvenir aux besoins de son enfant et participer ainsi au développement de sa communauté.

loans.use: Build supplies for his shop

loans.name: Sina's Yarabi Tupe Salama Group

texts.en:
Sina is 26 years. She is married with two children aged six and three. Sina has owned her own cafe since 2004. Every day, she works from 8am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

Sina now requests for a loan to buy more items for her cafe. She will share this loan with her sub-group member, Sharifa, who also has business dealing with her own shop.

loans.use: To buy more items for her cafe.

loans.name: Phalla

texts.en:
Mrs. Phalla S., 37, is a widow with one son, who studies in a local school. Phalla lives in a small village across the Mekong River about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh with her old mother, her son, and her sister who has full-time employment in Phnom Penh City. 

Mrs. Phalla has been a silk weaver for twenty one years, a skill she learned from her neighbor in 1987. She sells her finished products to the middle man in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. She hopes that her business will be able to support her son's studies to as high a level as possible.

Phalla is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase silk materials to continue her weaving business and to set up one new loom for her aunt to weave silk as well.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for weaving

loans.name: Virginia

texts.es:
La señora Virginia pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Siete Estrellas”, ubicado en la Av. San Martín  Nº 785 Interior B, distrito de Callería, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 39 años de edad, es madre de 2 hijos, 1 mayor de edad y  1 que aún depende de ella, es casada y su esposo trabaja como contador en una empresa privada. Con el primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 decidió invertir en una pequeña peluquería. Tiene 3 años trabajando con el Banco Comuanal.  

En la actualidad es profesora de Cosmetología y Educación por el Arte y cuenta con una peluquería en casa. Por las mañanas trabaja como docente y en las tardes se dedica a cambiar de look a todos sus clientes.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000, el cual será pagado en 6 meses, comprará 1 juego de sillas para ondular, 1 docena de acido de pelo, 2 docena de tinte de pelo, mandil, etc.  

Virginia es una mujer trabajadora que desea seguir adelante para el bienestar de su menor hija.
texts.en:
Virginia belongs to the "Las Siete Estrellas" [Seven Stars] communal bank located at Av. San Martín Nº 785 Interior B in Callería district, Ucayali. She is 39 years old and has two children, one of them grown up and the other still being raised. Virginia is married, her husband works as an accountant at a private company. She decided to invest the first loan of 300 soles she received from Manuela Ramos in a small hairdresser shop. She has been working with the communal bank for 3 years.

At present Virginia works as a cosmetics and arts teacher and manages a hairdresser shop in her home. She teaches in the mornings and changes the looks of all of her customers in the afternoons.

She will purchase a seat kit for perming, a dozen packages of hair acids, 2 dozen packages of dye, an apron etc.using the present loan of 1000 soles, which will be paid back in 6 months.

Virginia is a hardworking woman who wishes to make headway for the well-being of her younger daughter.

Translated from Spanish by Edit Pecsi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of seats, dyes, apron, etc.

loans.name: Em

texts.en: Mrs. Em N. was born in 1964 and lives in Kradass Khor village in the Kampong Cham Province. She is a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. Mao Mey, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land and cultivates rice to earn a living. She is requesting a loan to increase revenue by purchasing more land to cultivate rice. She has a child who is attending the local school. Her husband is presented on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To purcahse a plot of land to cultivate more rice.

loans.name: Nhor

texts.en:
Mrs. Nhor T. is a villager in Dambong Derk Village in Kampong Cham Province. She is a farmer who owns a small plot of land on which she cultivates rice. 

Her husband, Mr. Pin Tuong, is a cow breeder. Since his business is going well, he wants to expand it, so Mrs. Nhor T. has decided to ask for a loan to buy one more cow for her husband's business. 

Mrs. Nhor T. is 57 years old and the mother of two children who are employed in a garment factory.

loans.use: To buy another cow for her husband's business.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia E. is married and has 6 dependents. She has received no formal education. Cecilia sells "gari" which she uses cassava to produce. The raw cassava is milled and the starch extracted from it. The milled cassava is then fried to become "gari". It is popularly eaten in the country.

Cecilia also makes palm oil for sale at Elmina, which she has done since 2004. Her husband is a farmer. Cecilia uses her income to help her husband in paying rent, utility bills and other basic expenses of the family. Cecilia will use the loan to increase her capital to buy cassava and palm fruit in larger quantities for processing and sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Cecilia plans to reinvest back into the business to increase her profit margin so as to meet the financial needs of her large family.

The containers behind her are what she keeps the oil she produces in. She wasn't producing anything at the time this picture was taken, and that is why she was asked to sit by the containers.

loans.use: to increase her working capital to buy cassava and palm fruit in larger quantities

loans.name: Afia

texts.en:
Afia B. is 45 years old. She is married with seven children. Three of Afia's children are in school; one has passed away while the rest are independent.

Afia has been a local manufacturer of palm oil and palm kernel oil for twenty years now. Palm oil is produced from palm nuts while palm kernel oil is produced from palm kernels. The palm kernel is a by-product of palm oil. The palm kernel is also processed through various stages to obtain palm kernel oil which is used to prepare many local dishes. She produces both and supplies to food vendors to prepare their meals. She normally switches her production between the two products. That is, after producing palm oil she automatically obtains the raw material to produce palm kernel oil.

She wants to use the loan to buy more bags of palm nuts and an electric milling machine to increase her capacity to produce in larger quantities. She believes this will help expand her business to raise more income to help her husband provide support for her family and finance her children's education.

Afia belongs to a village bank called ‘Nyame Mpa Aba’ which means "God never gives up". She hopes to receive GHS 500 to make business progress by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To buy more bags of palm nuts and an electric milling machine

loans.name: Sây

texts.en:
V. is 57 years old and the father of four children. They all still live in the family home; two of them are employed; they live together in a medium-size wooden house in Battambang Province, Cambodia. V. currently cultivates rice and also raises oxen in a stall for their offspring. His wife's name is Savat, 49, and she is an employee of an electric company.

V.'s business raising oxen is running smoothly and has provided them income through selling the offspring. In order to make his business more successful and to earn more income, V. has requested a loan to buy more oxen to raise. (V.'s wife is pictured.)

loans.use: To buy more oxen

loans.name: Stone Quarry Group

texts.en:
Milly is a 35 year old woman who runs a retail shop and a small dairy business.

She has been in both of these businesses for 8 years and hopes they will both continue to grow as time goes on. In her dairy business, she currently has five cows but only two that provide milk for selling. From these two cows, she gets 9 liters of milk per day which she sells at 500 USH per liter. Milly spends most of her time at her retail shop. She tries to sell a very wide variety of items so that people can use her shop for all of their needs. In the future Milly would like to change her retail shop into a wholesale shop, because she thinks that this endeavor would be more profitable.

Today, Milly is requesting a loan of 1.5 million USH to restock her shop. Because Milly keeps her shop stocked with a large variety of items, she is unable to make bulk purchases of items. With this loan Milly plans to purchases items like sugar, posho flour, soda, soaps, etc.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, posho flour, soda, and other items.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan W. is currently in the business of selling food at a restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock more beans, flour, and vegetables for the resturant.  Susan is 20 years old and married with no children.  Her husband is a driver.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs for her restaurant

loans.name: Teofila

texts.es: Teofila es una madre de familia muy amorosa, tiene 43 años y vive en su propia casa junto a su único hijo Elvis de 9 años, y lo que más desea es darle una buena educación. La crianza de ganado es la actividad que desde muy niña realiza en la localidad de Jasana Capallino (Comunidad del distrito de Huancane), fue aprendiendo este negocio de sus padres, quienes siempre se preocuparon por darle una actividad con la cual defenderse en el futuro. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo a Teofila es pastar a sus animales, ya que disfruta mucho del aire libre, lleva 20 años en esta actividad y lo más difícil es llevar su ganado hasta las ferias dominicales de Huancane y Juliaca donde vende sus reses. Para el futuro espera incrementar la cantidad de ganado que tiene actualmente, para así mejor sus ingresos. Este es el primer préstamo de Teofila con MFP y está dispuesta a pagar todas sus cuotas puntualmente, en su banco comunal es una de las socias más cumplidas y puntuales. Con los 1000 soles solicitados comprará una ternerita lechera, la cual le costará aproximadamente 3500 soles, para completar ese monto pondrá parte de sus ahorros.
texts.en:
Teofila is a very caring mother who is 43 years old and lives in her own house along with her only son Elvis, who is 9 years old and for whom her main desire is to provide a good education. Raising livestock in the locality of Jasana Capallino (in the Huancane district), which she has done since she was little, is her economic activity. She learned this business from her parents, who always wanted to give her an activity with which to take care of herself in the future. What Teofila likes most about her job is shepherding the animals, since she enjoys the open air. In the 20 years she has done this work, the most difficult thing is taking her livestock to the Sunday markets in Huancane and Juliaca where she sells them. In the future, she hopes to increase the number of animals that she has to increase her income. This is her first loan with MFP and she is capable of making all of the payments punctually; in her communal bank she is one of the most punctual members. With the 1000 Soles requested she will buy a female calf, which will cost her 3500 Soles; to make up the rest she will use part of her savings.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a female calf

loans.name: Bozorgul

texts.ru: Холниезов Бозоргул Живет в районе Хуросон. Возраст 35 лет. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Бозоргул занимается купля, продажей крупно рогатого скота. Этим видом бизнеса занимается более 10 лет. Этот бизнес является основным источником дохода, для содержания семьи. Поэтому клиент хочет взять у нас кредит и купить несколько бычков.
texts.en:
H. Bozorgul lives in the Khuroson region. He is 35 years old. He is married and has 3 children. Bozorgul buys and sells livestock. He has been in this business for more than 10 years. This business is the main source of income for supporting his family. This is why the client would like to get credit from us and to purchase several bulls.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase livestock

loans.name: Santos Adelita

texts.es: Santos Adelita Rodríguez G. tiene 35 años, es madre soltera. Tiene 3 hijos uy todos estudian. Hace más de 10 años que se dedica a este negocio. La actividad económica es la pulpería. Ella decidió incursionar en este negocio por la mayoría de sus amistades le recomendaron que estableciera este tipo de negocio en su vivienda, y comenzó estableciendo una mesita de golosinas, pan, galletas entre otros, con el paso de el tiempo es que ha logrado incrementar su pequeño negocio y con la ayuda de los financiamientos. Santos solicita este financiamiento para capital de trabajo para la compra de granos básicos, golosinas, sopas instantáneas, jabón y detergente. Su sueño es obtener un mini súper y mejorar su vivienda.
texts.en:
Santos Adelita R. G. is a 35 year-old single mother. She has 3 children, all of whom are in school. For more than 10 years, Santos has run a small neighborhood grocery store, which she started at the recommendation of many of her friends. She began with a small table of sweets, bread, crackers, etc., and with time--and the occasional loan--she has been able to expand her small business. Santos is soliciting financing for the purchase of staple grains, candy, instant soups, soap, and detergent. Her dream is to start a small supermarket and improve her home.

Translated from Spanish by Cyrus Maher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Maxima

texts.en: Maxima M. is a widow who has been able to send her children to school with the profits she has made from her business of selling vegetables. She sells the vegetables, including beans from her own garden, in her village. She also sometimes sells "carabao" millk, "pnipig" and "soya" milk. Maxima is now asking Kiva lenders to support her most recent request for a loan of 7000 PHP to develop her business. She believes that this amount will greatly help to develop her business.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Mxima Audely

texts.es: Máxima Audely García Martínez tiene la edad de 43 años. Es madre soltera. Ella ha logrado darles a 2 hijos la educación necesaria. Su actividad económica es la venta de comida. Hace más de 9 años que se dedica a este humilde oficio. Anteriormente su Mama se dedicaba a este negocio, y fue algo que ella aprendió desde niña. Más tarde Máxima decide hacerse cargo muy contenta atiende a sus clientes para proporcionarles lo mejor, además Máxima está luchando muy fuerte porque además quiere dedicarse a vender ropa. Por lo que así podría aportar más ingresos para su familia. El financiamiento que solicita es para capital de trabajo para la compra de granos básicos. El sueño de Máxima es asegurar el futuro de sus hijos.
texts.en:
Máxima Audely García Martínez is 43 and a single mother. She has succeeded in giving her two children the education that they need. She sells food for a living and has done this for more than 9 years. Her mother used to have a business like this, so it is something that she learned how to do when she was a young girl. Later on, Máxima decided to run the business, and she is very happy attending to her customers so she can offer them the best. Máxima also works very hard because she also wants to sell clothing so she can have more income for her family. The financing she is requesting is for working capital so she can buy basic grains. Her dream is to secure her children's future.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Phea

texts.en: Phea P. was born in 1983 and a single woman. She was orphaned and therefore raised by her grandparents since she was very young. She is currently living with her other two siblings in the family home. Two of them are employed as construction workers. Since 2005, Phea P. has started selling various vegetable in the local market. She has also has a rice farming business. Phea P. is a determined lady who works hard to earn enough money to meet all her family’s needs. Phea P. has been planning to build a new house because her old house is small for all her family, but she lacks some money to make that possible. Therefore, she would like a loan from Kiva and will use it to add with her saving to build a new medium size wooden house. She is hopeful that the loan will improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To build a new medium size wooden house

loans.name: Hormiguitas Group

texts.es: Isabel M. Q. pertenece al grupo “Hormiguitas” del Centro Focal “German Busch”, tiene el negocio de venta de condimentos (sazonadores) en diferentes ferias de la ciudad de El Alto, ella necesita el préstamo para adquirir mayor mercadería, es decir, comprar ajo, comino y pimienta. Al igual que Isabel  las demás integrantes  del grupo cuentan con sus propios negocios como la venta  de ropa, alimento, cosméticos, chocolates y otras se dedican  a la costura de mantas, chamarras y fundas. Las que se dedican a la comercialización  de productos necesitan el préstamo para la compra de mercadería y las que producen para la compra de materia prima (tela, hilo y forro).
texts.en:
Isabel M. Q. belongs to the “Hormiguitas” [“Little Ants”] group from the center “German Busch”. Her business in the sale of condiments (sazonadores) at different markets in the city of El Alto. She needs this loan to acquire more merchandise, that is to say, to purchase garlic, cumin, and pepper. Like Isabel, the rest of the group members have their own businesses such as the sale of clothing, food, cosmetics, and chocolates, while others dedicate themselves to sowing blankets, jackets, and pillowcases. The group members that sell products need the loan to purchase merchandise, and those that produce need the loan to purchase basic materials (fabric, thread, and lining).

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise and basic materials.

loans.name: Maria Dominga

texts.es:
La señora María es casada, tiene 48 años, el nombre de su negocio es en alusión a uno de sus hijos, pues tiene 2 hijos, un varón y una mujer. Ambos ya son mayores de edad y trabajan; por lo tanto ya no depende del ingreso de la señora.
La despensa montó gracias a un pequeño capital que le había aportado su marido, el negocio tiene más de 19 años de antigüedad, con una vasta clientela y esta a nivel de la competencia. 
Ella necesita aumentar su stock de mercaderías para poder satisfacer la demanda, cabe destacar que es una persona muy trabajadora y con ganas de superación, por lo tanto, recomiendo a que se le apoye constantemente para que ella pueda alcanzar su meta. Su máximo sueño es mejorar su negocio y llegar a un nivel de vida superior a lo que está actualmente.

loans.use: Compra de Harinas, Yerbas, Vinos y Otros

loans.name: Norjmaa

texts.en:
Norjmaa lives with her three children and husband in a yurt-like Mongolian nomadic dwelling called a "ger" in the Chigeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. Her husband helps her with her business and her three children attend university and high school. 

Norjmaa is a salesperson. She started her business in 2000 in the Huchit Shonhor Market, one of the biggest local markets. She also has a little shop near her home that is managed by her children. Her husband is also very good at making wooden products, thus adding profits to their family earnings. She also buys animal fat in enormous amounts and makes cooking oils. 

She truly wants to increase her business profits and to contribute them for her children's future. Her dream is to make her counter bigger and redesign and repair their home to be more comfortable for all of the family members. She is requesting a 1, 000,000 tugrug ($725 USD) loan to purchase more products to sell and to repair her home.

loans.use: To purchase more food products to sell and to repair her home.

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en:
Jackline is a 23 year old mother of one. She lives and operates her retail shop in the Mukuru slums of Nairobi. She has been in this business for three years and hopes to develop it into a well established business.

She is requesting a loan of Ksh. 50,000 to enable her to add stock of household items and foodstuffs. She hopes to educate her children to the highest level and buy them a home. She describes herself as hardworking, focussed and determined.

About Kiva's partner Faulu Kenya: Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: Add stock

loans.name: Jocelyne

texts.fr: G. Jocelyne est née en 1947 et vit depuis trente neuf ans au quartier Cadjehoun à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Jocelyne est une veuve ayant trois enfants tous scolarisés dont deux sont à sa charge. Seule Jocelyne supporte les charges de la famille. Pour subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants, Jocelyne s’est mise depuis vingt ans dans la vente de maïs, de bois de chauffage et a également une cabine téléphonique où elle vend des recharges téléphoniques à la devanture de sa maison. Jocelyne s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé ayant bénéficié de trois crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés à ALIDé. Jocelyne sollicite un quatrième crédit de ALIDé pour accroitre son activité et satisfaire la demande nombreuse de ses clients.
texts.en:
Jocelyne G. was born in 1947 and has lived for thirty nine years in the Cadjehoun neighborhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Jocelyne is a widow with three children who are in school, two of whom she is supporting. Jocelyne meets the family's expenses alone. To meet her childrens' needs Jocelyne started selling corn and firewood twenty years ago, and she also has a telephone booth in front of her house where she sells telephone airtime refills. Jocelyne gets her supplies in Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin. She is a former client of Alidé, having benefited from three loans that she repaid correctly to Alidé. Jocelyne is requesting a fourth loan from Alidé to increase her business and to meet the numerous needs of her customers.

Translated from French by Heather Nicholson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase telephone refill cards, bags of corn, and firewood

loans.name: Sammy

texts.en:
Sammy is 47 years old, runs a barbershop in Burma Market in Nairobi and has two employees. He has been running his shop for one and one-half years and previously ran a video library. He is married with two children who are both attending school. He is requesting a loan of Kes. 20,000 to invest in his business.
Since joining Faulu, Sammy feels that he has become more serious about his business, such as keeping records properly, and has experienced high growth. He describes himself as hardworking and hopes to open many barbershops and employ more people in the future.


Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: Invest in his business

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Despite the hardships and difficulties of life, Marites D. and her husband want to send their eight children to school so that they will find a good job someday. They sacrifice their time and endure hardships for the sake of their children. The family lives in the village of Baresbes, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya.

As a way of making income, Marites' husband cultivates their farm lot by planting rice and vegetables, and sometimes he also works as a carpenter. Marites sells snacks and vegetables in their village to help her husband gain income. She wants to sell more snacks and vegetables, but she doesn't have enough capital. Therefore, she wants to borrow 7,000 PHP from Kiva lenders to be used in improving her small business. She hopes that through her patience and sacrifices, and with this financial assistance, she can make her business grow

loans.use: additional capital for her food production business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary sells crates of drinks. She is also a tailor and she makes lovely designs for her customers. She is 45 years old married with four children. Her husband is a pastor. She has been in business for five years. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to make a profit during this season. She is requesting a loan amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more crates of drinks to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Christian

texts.en: Christian is forty-three. She is married and a mother of three children, all in school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in one of the tourist attraction centres in Ghana. Since the community is a coastal town in the region, the majority of the inhabitants are fishermen/women. Christian is a hairdresser by profession. She has her workshop on one of the streets and has five apprentices who are currently under training. She says she has been in business for over twenty years and wants a loan to buy artificial hair and other working materials to be able to render better services to her valued clients.

loans.use: To buy artificial hair.

loans.name: Samson

texts.en:
Samson is 62 years old and married with eight children. He is a client of Kiva partner, Lift Above Poverty Organization. Samson has been selling groceries for a long time. He hopes to be able to support his children's education with the profits from his business. He is requesting a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more groceries to sell. He is grateful to all Kiva lenders.

About Lift Above Poverty Organization
Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Elshan

texts.en:
Elshan M. is a hardworking, enterprising man who started his business seven years ago so that he could have a better future. He buys and sells foodstuffs and he has an extensive clientele. Elshan understands the business very well so he has had great success. He hopes to keep expanding the business and increasing sales daily. He hopes his business will help him improve his situation and his quality of life. 

Elshan is asking for 1600 Azerbaijani manats to stock his store now that demand is increasing day by day. He is very grateful for your support in helping him expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase more items to sell

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Sonia M. comes from Jala-jala, Rizal province, in the Philippines. She is a 45-year-old married woman and the mother of five children. Four of her children are minors and the oldest is a first-year college student. All of them still need her support.  The couple has strong faith to improve their standard of living.

Sonia and her husband operate a welding stall. She started this business when ASHI gave her an opportunity to obtain a loan. The business is a big help to the family in covering their expenses and setting aside savings for the future. Now they are planning to buy a tricycle (motorcycle with sidecar) to have supplementary income to consistently provide the educational needs of their growing children.

The couple is requesting a loan of PHP 40,000 to buy a tricycle. They believe that proceeds from this business will give them money to support the immediate needs of their family.

Sonia hopes that her business will become successful someday. Along with the winning business, she is dreaming about seeing her five children graduate from college and find a stable job. She also still dreams of having a durable and concrete house of her own and saving for her family’s future.

loans.use: To buy a tricycle

loans.name: Lizel

texts.en:
Lizel L. is from the village of Pangantucan, Bukidnon. She is 22 years old. Lizel is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Lizel owns & operates a specialized retail store selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. Lizel has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Lizel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lizel is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Lizel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support needs of relatives and other family members. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Susan

texts.en: Susan is a 48-year-old married mother of three children who attend school. She has been running a cafeteria for four years and has two employees to assist her. She also distributes chicken to hotels to earn extra income. Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has learned how to save her money and her business has also grown. She hopes to expand her business and venture into other businesses in the future.  She has requested a loan of KES 60,000 to renovate her premises and buy a deep freezer.

loans.use: to renovate the premises and buy a deep freezer

loans.name: Elvira's Group

texts.en:
Elvira T. is from the village of Calamagui, San Pablo, Isabela. She is 48 years old. Elvira is the group leader of a 17-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Elvira is married and has 3 school-aged children. Elvira owns & operates a general store where she sells daily-use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste. Elvira has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Elvira joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Elvira has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. She is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Elvira from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to pay her children's tuition fees.  

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Kan

texts.en:
Mrs. Kan V. (pictured above), 51 and her husband, Mr. Korn Pho, 50, have been married since 1979 and have six children: four sons and two daughters. Three of them married and live outside the family home, one is a garment factory worker and the other two assist their parents in the farming business. They live in a small village about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Kan and her husband are farmers. They grow rice and vegetables. Besides farming, she wants to create a new business raising a cow. She will be able to get extra income from selling a cow when it grows big enough. Hence, Kan is requesting her first loan of $400 to purchase a cow to raise.

loans.use: To purchase a cow to raise.

loans.name: Bikamwa Plus Group

texts.en:
Bikamwa Plus is a Community Bank made up of 26 members whose chairwoman is Véronique. These members are united for the same goal: to grow their businesses by loans received from Kiva through the MFI HOPE RDC. 

Véronique sells corn and manioc flour. She began her business in 2000. After hard work and good management, she succeeded in making it thrive, thanks to the accumulated profits. Véronique is a trustworthy client of the MFI HOPE RDC, having five times obtained and correctly repaid loans. She will increase her stock of merchandise with her next loan by buying ten 10kg/sacks of corn and manioc flour and reselling them at a profit. Véronique is 60 years old. She is married and the mother of 6 children, whose ages range between 8 and 35 years old. Only one of her children attends school. Her business generates a profit of $35 per week. Véronique’s dream is to open a manioc and corn facility and become a provider in her area.

loans.use: Towards purchasing 10 10kg/sacks of corn and manioc flour and reselling them at a profit

loans.name: Rysalieva's Group

texts.en:
Today it is quite difficult to overestimate the value and importance of small loans. These loans have proven to be the driving economic force in developing countries, changing the lives of millions of ordinary people and helping them not only to accomplish their plans, but also to save tremendous amount of time. The heroes of this story are a sample from the societies of the third world:

S. Rysalieva is the widowed 57-year-old leader of this group. She has raised two daughters, 40 and 25, both living and working in Russia. S. makes her living by raising cattle and selling milk, having started the business after selling the big house her family lived in and downsizing. During the past years, they have been able to buy a second house and now S. has a stable monthly income of $70. While this is not a large amount, considering her age she is doing quite well. Now, S. is in need of a loan to effect repairs to her kitchen.

S.’s partners:

N. Israilova, a 26-year-old married mother of three children, earns her family livelihood by providing seamstress services as she manufactures national articles. Now, N. hopes to get this loan to buy a cow.

A. Turdugulova, 27, a divorced mother of a five-year-old son, breeds cattle and sells milk, earning around $40 per month. With this loan, she will be able to purchase sheep for breeding.

M. Koichukeeva, 29, married with three children, breeds cattle and sells milk with her husband, earning a stable income of $205 a month. Now M. is requesting this loan to make a house repair.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan delivering its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To repair the kitchen

loans.name: Simon

texts.en: Simon G. W. is forty nine years old. He is married. He and his wife have six children, to whom they hope to give a good education. He does his business of providing transport services to the people of Thika. He has been in this business for the last two years and he says the business is good. Although, at times,he is detracted by rains. He is using his loan of KES20,000 to buy another motorcycle to expand his business. He hopes to buy a farm with his profits. He is hardworking and cheerful.

loans.use: To purchase a motor cycle.

loans.name: Valentin

texts.en:
Valentin S. S. is a 45-year-old pepper producer who lives in the region of Coquital de Los Chiles de San Carlos, located in Northern Costa Rica. The rural zone where Valentin and his family live is one of the few places in Costa Rica without running water; the family must pump water from a nearby well as needed. Valentin is working hard towards the sustenance of his family, striving to reap the maximum benefits from his land and his labour.

Valentin is a dedicated farmer who plans to focus his efforts on the planting and harvest of cayenne peppers. He works in cooperation with his wife to strike a balance between accomplishing the daily tasks associated with agricultural production and the completion of domestic responsibilities. The land they work is their own. In addition to his agricultural activity, Valentin works at a local orange-processing factory as a harvesting laborer in order to supplement the family income. The money he earns helps pay bills for electricity and food. 

Although this is an individual loan, the community in which Valentin and his family live is very close-knit and interdependent. Neighbors help and support one another by sharing experiences and expertise acquired over the years. All members of the Coquital community are dedicated to the improvement of living conditions for the region as a whole.

This loan will be used to finance the production of cayenne peppers. Specifically, the loan will be used to finance the purchase of a variety of seedlings and necessary agricultural nutrients, fertilizers and chemicals in order to ensure a healthy harvest. All labor and logistical tasks associated with production will be carried out by Valentin with the help of his family members. Valentin will need roughly one year before his peppers reach maturity and are ready for harvest.

Piper and Capiscum Processors Compañía Agrícola Industrial, or PROPICA, is an international buyer and seller of chili pepper and ground pepper products. In cooperation with Fundación Mujer, PROPICA has guaranteed to purchase the agricultural products (the peppers) that are to be produced with the help of this loan. PROPICA acts as a guaranteed client for small agricultural producers in the area of Coquital, thus ensuring that their products will reach market.

In general, the work day is divided into mornings and afternoons. In the mornings, the domestic tasks are carried out such as cooking and cleaning. Afternoons are generally dedicated to harvesting, planting, and working the land as needed. Valentin spends some days working as a laborer in the nearby orange-processing factory but this work is sporadic.

Valentin says the main factor that has stood in the way of increasing his production levels has been the Costa Rican government and various other institutions. Formal banks, lending agencies and government bodies have failed to recognize the producers of the Coquital region as legitimate producers, worthy of financial and governmental support and services.

The collaboration of Fundación Mujer and PROPICA represents a unique opportunity to Valentin, his family and his community. By offering a source of start-up capital and a guaranteed client to purchase what is produced, this is a chance to improve family and community standards of living. Above all, Valentin wants to take advantage of the current opportunity that has been presented; he wants to profit from this collaboration and see improvements in his neighborhood.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and nutrients necessary for producing peppers

loans.name: Fabián Vicente

texts.es:
Fabián Vicente Q. V. tiene 25 años. Es soltero y vive con sus padres en el cantón de Chillanes en la provincia de Bolívar.

Fabián es un socio de la ventanilla rural Santa Rosa, que está ubicada a una hora y media del cantón Chillanes.  Son 18 socios en total, que en la mayoridad tienen sus propios negocios. Esto es el primer  préstamo que ellos sacan con la Cooperativa San José.

Fabián se dedica a la agricultura. Vende sus productos en Chillanes y hace las compras en Bucay. 

Solicita el préstamo para invertir en un negocio para vender sus productos agrícolas. Su sueño es  tener un gran negocio para su futuro. 

Le gusta jugar fútbol en su tiempo libre.
texts.en:
Fabián Vicente Q. V. is 25 years old. He is single, and he lives with his parents in the Chillanes canton in the Bolívar province. Fabián is a member of the Santa Rosa Communal Bank, which is located one and a half hours from the Chillanes canton. There are 18 members in all. Most of them have their own businesses. This is their first loan with the Cooperativa San José. Fabián is a farmer. He sells his products in Chillanes and makes his purchases in Bucay. He is requesting a loan to invest in his business in order to sell his agricultural products. His dream is to have a great business in the future. He likes to play soccer in his free time.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in his business in order to sell his agricultural products

loans.name: Seom

texts.en:
Seom V., 63, is widowed and resides with her six children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. V. stays at home. Her son is a skillful fisherman and sells fish for an income of $3 per day. Her daughter grows fruit trees, earning an income of $2 per day. 

V. is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase fishing tools for her son to improve his business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  

This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. V.'s son appears in the photograph with his fishing tools.

loans.use: Buy fishing tools to improve the current business

loans.name: Rano

texts.en:
Rano D. is the divorced mother of two children. She is a private entrepreneur who works in the central city market selling women’s shoes. She offers a large variety of shoes at reasonable prices. Rano has been in business for 10 years. She has benefited a lot from 4 years of partnering with IMON International, Tajikistan. Lending services have helped her buy a new vending facility in a different part of the city, reach sustainability in her business, and have given her confidence for the future. Rano requests a loan of 5000 Somoni to re-stock her inventory and purchase shoes wholesale for the summer season. She believes that the sphere of market trade where she works is a promising niche and will continue to grow and develop in the future. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy summer stock for her shoe store.

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida C. is from the village of Upper Langcangan Oroq. City Misamis Occidental. She is 57 years old. Zenaida is married and has six adult-aged children. To make a living, Zenaida owns and operates a specialized retail store, where she sells goods like candy, biscuits, and soap in the local community. Zenaida has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Zenaida joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Zenaida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. Zenaida is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be invested in expanding the business. This will be Zenaida's sixth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more goods to expand the business

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
Leticia C. is from the village of Andarayan South, Solana, Cagayan. She is 29 years old. Leticia is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Leticia owns & operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing manicure and pedicure services in the local community. Leticia has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Leticia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leticia is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Leticia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to expand services provided

loans.name: Gertrudes

texts.en:
Gertrudes O. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. Kaungkod, Madredijos, Cebu City. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  general store and pig fattening businesses. Her husband Juan O., who is 48 years old, works as a carpenter to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have five children who are 15 to 22 years old. 

Gertrudes joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 12 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Gertrudes has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4000 thus, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 13 loan, she is borrowing PHP 29,000, which she intends to use to purchase more stock to sell so that she can continue to save up for her family's future security and improve their living conditions. She also wants to save enough so that she can have additional capital to invest back to her businesses. Gertrudes O. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:

 In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable).
